leanCodeSectionsTree.body: User note: Code change proposals to sections preceded by the designation [F] will be considered by the International Fire Code Development Committee during the 2016 (Group B) Code Development Cycle. See explanation on page iv.

children.body: Buildings or portions thereof shall be provided with a means of egress system as required by this chapter. The provisions of this chapter shall control the design, construction and arrangement of means of egress components required to provide an approved means of egress from structures and portions thereof.

It shall be unlawful to alter a building or structure in a manner that will reduce the number of exits or the minimum width or required capacity of the means of egress to less than required by this code.

diagrams.title: Egress: Min. Reqs., Existing Buildings
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1001.2 is to ensure that the means of egress in an existing building are not altered beyond what the code considers safe. It requires that the number of required exits is not reduced below the code required minimum for any area, space or building. It also requires that the means of egress width and capacity of the various means of egress elements that comprise the system are not reduced below the code required minimum and would apply to all required elements of the means of egress.

children.body: Means of egress shall be maintained in accordance with the International Fire Code.

Fire safety and evacuation plans shall be provided for all occupancies and buildings where required by the International Fire Code. Such fire safety and evacuation plans shall comply with the applicable provisions of Sections 401.2 and 404 of the International Fire Code.

diagrams.title: Projections in Nursing Home Corridors
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In Group I-2, Condition 1 occupancies, as long as the corridor width is not less than 96", furniture is allowed to project into the corridor as long as the furniture is attached to the floor or wall, does not reduce the clear width to less than 72", is positioned on only one side of the corridor, does not exceed 50 sq. ft. in area, is separated from other furniture pieces by 10' minimum and it is considered as part of the dire and safety plans in accordance with Section 1002.2.

diagrams.title: Fire and Emerg. Plans
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1002.2 of the Building Code states that fire safety and evacuation plans are to be in place and approved by the AHJ for those occupancies where the Fire Code requires them. The occupancies that require these plans are listed in Section 403, with each occupancy type having specific guidelines for their plan creation. Section 404 of the Fire Code defines and outlines the contents of three specific types of plans: fire evacuation (404.2.1), fire safety (404.2.2), and lockdown plans (404.2.3). Each of these plans may have overlapping and interconnecting sections. The fire evacuation plans focus on how and where to move people in case of a fire in each part of a building. The fire safety plan covers actions to be taken in case of fire, fire prevention and maintenance of equipment, and refers to evacuation plan for people movement in case of fire. Lockdown plans cover the threats and hazards, initiation, and termination of lockdown procedures and conditions.

diagrams.title: Elevators, Escalators or Moving Walks in Means of Egress
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Because mechanical devices are prone to failure due to loss of power in an emergency situation Section 1003.7 does not permit them to be used as a required means of egress. This Section only applies to Elevators, escalators and moving walks. There is a special exception for where an elevator needs to be used to provide an accessible means of egress and requires the elevator to comply with section 1009.4. Section 1009.4 requires stand-by power may require an areas of refuge.

diagrams.title: Exit Access, Exit and Exit Discharge
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The building code defines exit, exit access and exit discharge as the following:

Exit Access: That portion of a means of egress system that leads from any occupied portion of a building or structure to an exit.

Exit: That portion of a means of egress system between the exit access and the exit discharge or public way. Exit components include exterior exit doors at the level of exit discharge, interior exit stairways and ramps, exit passageways, exterior exit stairways and ramps and horizontal exits.

Exit Discharge: That portion of a means of egress system between the termination of an exit and a public way.

children.body:
The means of egress shall have a ceiling height of not less than 7 feet 6 inches (2286 mm).
Exceptions:
  1. Sloped ceilings in accordance with Section 1208.2.
  2. Ceilings of dwelling units and sleeping units within residential occupancies in accordance with Section 1208.2.
  3. Allowable projections in accordance with Section 1003.3.
  4. Stair headroom in accordance with Section 1011.3.
  5. Door height in accordance with Section 1010.1.1.
  6. Ramp headroom in accordance with Section 1012.5.2.
  7. The clear height of floor levels in vehicular and pedestrian traffic areas of public and private parking garages in accordance with Section 406.4.1.
  8. Areas above and below mezzanine floors in accordance with Section 505.2.
  9. The exit discharge and exit passageways in a means of egress system shall be allowed to have a ceiling height of not less than 7 feet (2134 mm).

diagrams.title: Stairway Headroom and Vert. Rise
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Stairways require a minimum amount of headroom height. When placing stairways on a plan, always be sure to check if the stair when viewed in section, with the required rise and run of the treads, won't conflict with the floor above as as person comes up or down the stairs. Ways to fix this in the field can be undesirable aesthetically or expensive.

In addition, stairways that are too long could be dangerous from falls, or could be too physically taxing for those not able to sustain the effort to traverse a long stairway. Therefore, stair runs are limited to 12 feet in vertical rise.

diagrams.title: Min. Means of Egress Ceiling Heights
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Provisions for minimum ceiling heights include the minimum allowed heights to ceilings, protrusions, headers and other structural elements and mechanical or plumbing systems including fire sprinklers. The provisions provide allowances in dwelling units for the provision of space for ventilation in corridors (by use of a reduced ceiling height) or the condition where a room walls include the sloping roof, which reduces the ceiling height in a portion of the room. There are exceptions in the existing building code where pre-existing non-conforming ceiling heights may be allowed to remain.

children.body: Protruding objects on circulation paths shall comply with the requirements of Sections 1003.3.1 through 1003.3.4.

diagrams.title: Means of Egress Continuity: Obstructions
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Obstructions by building elements are not permitted to be installed within the means of egress. For example, where a minimum egress width of 44" is required, no obstruction or building element can project into the 44" space, which would decrease the width of the space. If the required width is 44", but the total width of the corridor is 50" then a building element could project up to 6" into the space. This would not impede or decrease the required egress width.

Obstructions must also comply with provisions for projections and obstructions in the applicable accessibility code / ADA. While some obstructions or projections may be allowed by egress provisions, they may require special treatment so not to provide a hazard to the vision impaired.

diagrams.title: Corridors: Unobstructed Width
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The unobstructed width of a corridor is determined based on the specific occupancy and utilization of the structure. Corridors must maintain their minimum required width or capacity unobstructed, to ensure safe and easy passage. However, under specific circumstances, exceptions are allowed which include encroachments complying with Section 1005.7.

diagrams.title: Recessed Objects
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Some objects are necessary, or even required by code, such as drinking fountains, that can create a non-compliant protruding object situation. One remedy would be to recess the object in a pocket in the wall, such as along a corridor. Care must be taken to provide proper knee space, width for wheelchair use and to not restrict the adjacent accessible route to less than the minimum required at that location.

diagrams.descriptionHtml: Provisions for minimum ceiling heights include the minimum allowed heights to ceilings, protrusions, headers and other structural elements and mechanical or plumbing systems including fire sprinklers. The provisions provide allowances in dwelling units for the provision of space for ventilation in corridors (by use of a reduced ceiling height) or the condition where a room walls include the sloping roof, which reduces the ceiling height in a portion of the room. There are exceptions in the existing building code where pre-existing non-conforming ceiling heights may be allowed to remain.

diagrams.title: Protruding Object Limits
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Various items that might be considered protruding objects could include diagonal structural brace frame elements, overhanging stair landings, architectural features, wall mounted objects and signs among others. If items such as planters or other objects are used to provide cane detection, consideration should be given to the permanence or possible future moving (for items like furniture) or maintenance of the object (like planters). If the item that is provided to provide cane detection is moved, a violation of the requirement would occur.

ADA Advisory 307.2 Protrusion Limits. When a cane is used and the element is in the detectable range, it gives a person sufficient time to detect the element with the cane before there is body contact. Elements located on circulation paths, including operable elements, must comply with requirements for protruding objects. For example, awnings and their supporting structures cannot reduce the minimum required vertical clearance. Similarly, casement windows, when open, cannot encroach more than 4 inches into circulation paths above 27 inches.

children.body:
Protruding objects are permitted to extend below the minimum ceiling height required by Section 1003.2 where a minimum headroom of 80 inches (2032 mm) is provided over any walking surface, including walks, corridors, aisles and passageways. Not more than 50 percent of the ceiling area of a means of egress shall be reduced in height by protruding objects.
Exception: Door closers and stops shall not reduce headroom to less than 78 inches (1981 mm).

A barrier shall be provided where the vertical clearance is less than 80 inches (2032 mm) high. The leading edge of such a barrier shall be located 27 inches (686 mm) maximum above the floor.

diagrams.title: Protruding Objects: Headroom
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Because circulation paths, walks, corridors, aisles, and passageways are used for egress and egress access, the code limits the minimum ceiling height to stop smoke and other contaminants from preventing safe egress in the event of an emergency. Section 1003.3.1 ensures that any protruding objects do not lower the ceiling to a point that makes the building egress unreasonably safe. Over areas required for the means of egress protruding objects may reduce the ceiling height to 80" minimum. The aggregate area of protruding objects over a means of egress cannot exceed 50% of the ceiling area of the means of egress. Protruding objects not over the required egress width may be less than 80" when provided with a barrier, often referred to as cane detection. The barrier cannot exceed a height of 27". The code does provide an exception for door stops and closers which may not be less than 78" above the floor.

children.body:
A free-standing object mounted on a post or pylon shall not overhang that post or pylon more than 4 inches (102 mm) where the lowest point of the leading edge is more than 27 inches (686 mm) and less than 80 inches (2032 mm) above the walking surface. Where a sign or other obstruction is mounted between posts or pylons and the clear distance between the posts or pylons is greater than 12 inches (305 mm), the lowest edge of such sign or obstruction shall be 27 inches (686 mm) maximum or 80 inches (2032 mm) minimum above the finished floor or ground.
Exception: These requirements shall not apply to sloping portions of handrails between the top and bottom riser of stairs and above the ramp run.

Objects with leading edges more than 27 inches (685 mm) and not more than 80 inches (2030 mm) above the floor shall not project horizontally more than 4 inches (102 mm) into the circulation path.
Exception: Handrails are permitted to protrude 41/2 inches (114 mm) from the wall.

diagrams.title: Stairs Horizontal Encroachments
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Generally, projections of more than 4" are not allowed into the circulation path. This doesn't include the 48" clear width between handrails for stairways used as an accessible means of egress.

The allowance for a 1-1/2" projection into the required width for trim or other non-structural projection at the base would not include structural items such as stringers for steel pan-tread type stairways. The minimum required stair width would have to be accommodated for between the structural items in that condition.

children.body: Protruding objects shall not reduce the minimum clear width of accessible routes.

children.body: Walking surfaces of the means of egress shall have a slip-resistant surface and be securely attached.

diagrams.title: Slip-Resistant Surfaces
diagrams.descriptionHtml: While there does not appear to be a building code definition of "slip-resistant", or "securely attached", care should be taken to make sure that aspects of means of egress are safe for use in the event the floor is wet for various reasons, and tripping hazards from loose mats are not in the means of egress.

Where changes in elevation of less than 12 inches (305 mm) exist in the means of egress, sloped surfaces shall be used. Where the slope is greater than one unit vertical in 20 units horizontal (5-percent slope), ramps complying with Section 1012 shall be used. Where the difference in elevation is 6 inches (152 mm) or less, the ramp shall be equipped with either handrails or floor finish materials that contrast with adjacent floor finish materials.
Exceptions:
  1. A single step with a maximum riser height of 7 inches (178 mm) is permitted for buildings with occupancies in Groups F, H, R-2, R-3, S and U at exterior doors not required to be accessible by Chapter 11.
  2. A stair with a single riser or with two risers and a tread is permitted at locations not required to be accessible by Chapter 11 where the risers and treads comply with Section 1011.5, the minimum depth of the tread is 13 inches (330 mm) and not less than one handrail complying with Section 1014 is provided within 30 inches (762 mm) of the centerline of the normal path of egress travel on the stair.
  3. A step is permitted in aisles serving seating that has a difference in elevation less than 12 inches (305 mm) at locations not required to be accessible by Chapter 11, provided that the risers and treads comply with Section 1029.13 and the aisle is provided with a handrail complying with Section 1029.15.
Throughout a story in a Group I-2 occupancy, any change in elevation in portions of the means of egress that serve nonambulatory persons shall be by means of a ramp or sloped walkway.

The path of egress travel along a means of egress shall not be interrupted by a building element other than a means of egress component as specified in this chapter. Obstructions shall not be placed in the minimum width or required capacity of a means of egress component except projections permitted by this chapter. The minimum width or required capacity of a means of egress system shall not be diminished along the path of egress travel.

Elevators, escalators and moving walks shall not be used as a component of a required means of egress from any other part of the building.
Exception: Elevators used as an accessible means of egress in accordance with Section 1009.4.

diagrams.title: Escalator Openings (New Const.)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: To protect occupants on the floor above from fire and smoke passing through escalator floor openings the code limits the size of the floor opening for an escalator to twice the projected area of the escalator. The code requires a draft curtain to limit smoke's ability to migrate up to the floor above. To prevent a fire from spreading through the escalator opening closely spaced sprinklers are required around the opening. Escalator floor openings may not connect more than 4 stories except in Group B and M occupancies.

diagrams.title: Occupant Load Calc: Small Space
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Single-Occupancy Category B, Restaurant, Non-Sprinklered

UpCodes Note: Restroom/Corridor is not normally occupied area, and major use is assembly (seating), based on "net area". Restroom/Corridor area is excluded from occupant load calculation.

The determination of occupant loads and occupancy groups are independent. Even though the occupancy group for a small assembly area may be a Group B occupancy group, the occupant load factor for "Assembly: Without Tables and Chairs" would be used if the space functions in that way. The building code does not specifically address whether to round occupant loads up at the room level, or the overall space. Rounding at the space level is shown here. Check with your local jurisdiction for local policies on rounding.

When adding additional occupant loads, be sure and verify with other code requirements, such as accessibility, exit discharge and also separate bathroom requirements, are not violated. In this instance, increasing the occupant load to larger than what is allowed for a single user restroom could require an additional restroom be added, making the proposed addition problematic. In cases such as this, close working with the Building Official and consideration of the Existing Building code requirements should be considered to determine if an additional bathroom should be added.

diagrams.title: Cumulative Occ. Loads: Mezzanines
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The room or space that a mezzanine exits through is considered to be a catchment space where the occupant load of both are accumulated before the exiting from the main space is calculated for width and number of exits.

diagrams.title: Cumulative Occ. Loads: Intervening Spaces/Accessory Areas
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Cumulative occupant loads affect egress design when occupants must pass through shared or intervening spaces en route to an exit. When multiple rooms discharge through a common space, that space must be designed to accommodate the total number of occupants that pass through it—not just its own occupant load.

This approach ensures the egress system is appropriately sized for actual use conditions. However, it's important to understand that this requirement applies only to the occupants who traverse the shared path. If a space has multiple exit routes and some occupants do not use the intervening area, only those who do contribute to the cumulative load at that point. This avoids artificially inflating the required egress capacity by counting occupants twice.

Architects should take care during the early planning stages to analyze not just the occupant load of rooms, but also the actual flow of occupants during egress, tracing how people move through space and identifying bottlenecks. It's especially important in open or hybrid layouts—such as coworking areas, medical offices, or tenant spaces within larger occupancies—where paths of travel may be shared or split. Misinterpreting who contributes to the cumulative load can lead to over- or under-designing critical egress components, affecting code compliance and occupant safety.

diagrams.title: Means of Egress: Multiple Occupancies
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
When a building is comprised of multiple occupancies, the means of egress serving each occupancy shall apply to that portion of the building for which it is provided.

Example 1: in a building that is part B occupancy and part H-4 occupancy where each is provided it's own exit corridor, the exit corridor within and exclusively serving the B occupancy need not be rated and the exit corridor within and exclusively serving the H-4 occupancy is required to have a 1-hour fire resistance (per Table 1020.1). When a means of egress component is utilized or shared by two or more occupancies the component shall be required to meet the most stringent requirements of the occupancies served.

Example 2: in a mixed use building where a B occupancy and an H-4 occupancy share an exit corridor the exit corridor must have a 1-hour fire resistance rating as that (as we know from Example 1) is the most stringent corridor requirement of the uses that will share the corridor. The applicable requirements apply to the entire component, not just the walls or elements adjacent to each occupancy, i.e. both sides of the corridor for the entire length in the example would be required to meet the requirements for 1-hour fire resistant construction for it to be shared by both a B and H-4 occupancy.

diagrams.title: Gross Area Calc.
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Calculating the gross floor area is essential for understanding various aspects of a building, including occupant load and fire safety requirements. In the building code, the gross floor area is determined as the area included within surrounding exterior walls, or exterior walls and fire walls, exclusive of vent shafts and courts (Building Code Section 202). For areas without surrounding walls, they are included in the gross floor area if they fall within the horizontal projection of a roof or floor above. Next, sum the results of all areas calculated for each floor together to get the total gross floor area.

diagrams.title: Example: OL, Exits and Common Path of Travel
Occupant Load Calc: Gallery (2015)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
When designing a building with floors that contain rooms or areas dedicated to different functions, it's essential to calculate the design occupant load for each area independently. The occupant load factor (OLF) for each specific function is determined by Table 1004.1.2. Architects and engineers must differentiate between net and gross floor areas in their calculations. Net floor area excludes unoccupied accessory spaces such as corridors, stairs, ramps, restrooms, and closets, while gross floor area encompasses these accessory spaces.

The design process involves categorizing various areas according to their function within the building. To calculate the occupant load, divide the area (whether net or gross) of each function by its corresponding OLF from Table 1004.1.2, then sum the occupant loads for all functions. Designers may encounter scenarios where a space's function doesn't directly match any listed in the table. In such cases, it's necessary to choose the function that most closely aligns with the intended use of the space. For instance, an art gallery with common workshop areas for activities like framing paintings, or more production-like activities like welding and other fabrication processes could classify these workshops under an industrial area, as it most closely resembles the activities' nature, according to Table 1004.1.2.

children.body: In determining means of egress requirements, the number of occupants for whom means of egress facilities are provided shall be determined in accordance with this section.

diagrams.title: Single Exits: Multiple Occupancies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Single exits are permitted to serve multiple occupancies and multiple stories provided a number of additional limitations are met by the design. For a single exit, exit access stairway or ramp to serve a story with multiple occupancies each occupancy in and of itself must meet the requirements of Table 1006.3.3(1) or Table 1006.3.3(2). In addition where a single exit serves a story or multiple stories the sum of the ratios for each occupancy of the design occupant load divided by the allowable occupant load from Table 1006.3.3(2) for each story served by the exit must not exceed 1. When dwelling units are on a floor, the ratio used for dwelling units in the summation is the number of dwelling units divided by 4.

diagrams.title: Occupant Loads: Retail
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Even though the restroom and corridor is not normally occupied area, the major use is Mercantile. Based on the definition of "gross area", the restroom and corridor area is included in occupant load calculation. The diagram shown is based on the 2018 codes which allows an Occupant Load Factor of 150 instead of 100 for business areas.

The building code does not specifically address whether to round occupant loads up at the room level, or the overall space. Rounding at the room level is shown here. Check with your local jurisdiction for local policies on rounding.

children.body: Where the path of egress travel includes intervening rooms, areas or spaces, cumulative occupant loads shall be determined in accordance with this section.

Where occupants egress from one or more rooms, areas or spaces through others, the design occupant load shall be the combined occupant load of interconnected accessory or intervening spaces. Design of egress path capacity shall be based on the cumulative portion of occupant loads of all rooms, areas or spaces to that point along the path of egress travel.

diagrams.descriptionHtml: The room or space that a mezzanine exits through is considered to be a catchment space where the occupant load of both are accumulated before the exiting from the main space is calculated for width and number of exits.

children.body: Other than for the egress components designed for convergence in accordance with Section 1005.6, the occupant load from separate stories shall not be added.

The number of occupants shall be computed at the rate of one occupant per unit of area as prescribed in Table 1004.1.2. For areas without fixed seating, the occupant load shall be not less than that number determined by dividing the floor area under consideration by the occupant load factor assigned to the function of the space as set forth in Table 1004.1.2. Where an intended function is not listed in Table 1004.1.2, the building official shall establish a function based on a listed function that most nearly resembles the intended function.
Exception: Where approved by the building official, the actual number of occupants for whom each occupied space, floor or building is designed, although less than those determined by calculation, shall be permitted to be used in the determination of the design occupant load.

diagrams.title: Occupant Load Calc: Small Space
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Single-Occupancy Category B, Restaurant, Non-Sprinklered

UpCodes Note: Restroom/Corridor is not normally occupied area, and major use is assembly (seating), based on "net area". Restroom/Corridor area is excluded from occupant load calculation.

The determination of occupant loads and occupancy groups are independent. Even though the occupancy group for a small assembly area may be a Group B occupancy group, the occupant load factor for "Assembly: Without Tables and Chairs" would be used if the space functions in that way. The building code does not specifically address whether to round occupant loads up at the room level, or the overall space. Rounding at the space level is shown here. Check with your local jurisdiction for local policies on rounding.

When adding additional occupant loads, be sure and verify with other code requirements, such as accessibility, exit discharge and also separate bathroom requirements, are not violated. In this instance, increasing the occupant load to larger than what is allowed for a single user restroom could require an additional restroom be added, making the proposed addition problematic. In cases such as this, close working with the Building Official and consideration of the Existing Building code requirements should be considered to determine if an additional bathroom should be added.

diagrams.title: Example: Single Exit Condition
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Single-Occupancy Category B, Non-Sprinklered

Spaces are allowed to have only a single exit if they have less than a prescribed amount of occupants, depending on the occupancy group. Also, the common path of egress travel must be less than that allowed by Table 1006.2.1. However, dead end corridors themselves are not limited when only one exit is required.

diagrams.title: Gross Area Calc.
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Calculating the gross floor area is essential for understanding various aspects of a building, including occupant load and fire safety requirements. In the building code, the gross floor area is determined as the area included within surrounding exterior walls, or exterior walls and fire walls, exclusive of vent shafts and courts (Building Code Section 202). For areas without surrounding walls, they are included in the gross floor area if they fall within the horizontal projection of a roof or floor above. Next, sum the results of all areas calculated for each floor together to get the total gross floor area.

diagrams.title: Example: OL, Exits and Common Path of Travel
Occupant Loads: Retail
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Even though the restroom and corridor is not normally occupied area, the major use is Mercantile. Based on the definition of "gross area", the restroom and corridor area is included in occupant load calculation. The diagram shown is based on the 2018 codes which allows an Occupant Load Factor of 150 instead of 100 for business areas.

The building code does not specifically address whether to round occupant loads up at the room level, or the overall space. Rounding at the room level is shown here. Check with your local jurisdiction for local policies on rounding.

diagrams.title: Min. Stairway Widths and Loss of Exit
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
For floors utilizing stairs as a means of egress the minimum required combined width of the stairs is determined by multiplying the occupant load for the floor served by the egress capacity factor of 0.3". Egress stairs must be built in accordance with Section 1011, which requires a 44" minimum stair width. Exceptions apply for buildings protected throughout by an automatic sprinkler system and protected by an EVACS system, for smoke-protected assembly seating, and for open air assembly seating.

If one stair is becomes no longer available for service, then the remaining stairs are required to provide at least 50% of the required capacity or width.

diagrams.title: Egress Req. for Temporary Structures
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Temporary structures are those erected for a period of less than 180 days. These structures include special event structures, tents, umbrella structures, and other membrane structures that meet the specified duration requirements. Temporary structures are expected to conform to the structural strength, fire safety, means of egress, accessibility, light, ventilation, and sanitary requirements of the building code to ensure public health, safety, and general welfare. Exit access distance shall not exceed 100 feet, and it must comply with the applicable accessibility requirements as well.

diagrams.title: Occupant Load Calc: Gallery (2015)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
When designing a building with floors that contain rooms or areas dedicated to different functions, it's essential to calculate the design occupant load for each area independently. The occupant load factor (OLF) for each specific function is determined by Table 1004.1.2. Architects and engineers must differentiate between net and gross floor areas in their calculations. Net floor area excludes unoccupied accessory spaces such as corridors, stairs, ramps, restrooms, and closets, while gross floor area encompasses these accessory spaces.

The design process involves categorizing various areas according to their function within the building. To calculate the occupant load, divide the area (whether net or gross) of each function by its corresponding OLF from Table 1004.1.2, then sum the occupant loads for all functions. Designers may encounter scenarios where a space's function doesn't directly match any listed in the table. In such cases, it's necessary to choose the function that most closely aligns with the intended use of the space. For instance, an art gallery with common workshop areas for activities like framing paintings, or more production-like activities like welding and other fabrication processes could classify these workshops under an industrial area, as it most closely resembles the activities' nature, according to Table 1004.1.2.

children.body: The occupant load permitted in any building, or portion thereof, is permitted to be increased from that number established for the occupancies in Table 1004.1.2, provided that all other requirements of the code are met based on such modified number and the occupant load does not exceed one occupant per 7 square feet (0.65 m2) of occupiable floor space. Where required by the building official, an approved aisle, seating or fixed equipment diagram substantiating any increase in occupant load shall be submitted. Where required by the building official, such diagram shall be posted.

Every room or space that is an assembly occupancy shall have the occupant load of the room or space posted in a conspicuous place, near the main exit or exit access doorway from the room or space. Posted signs shall be of an approved legible permanent design and shall be maintained by the owner or the owner's authorized agent.

For areas having fixed seats and aisles, the occupant load shall be determined by the number of fixed seats installed therein. The occupant load for areas in which fixed seating is not installed, such as waiting spaces, shall be determined in accordance with Section 1004.1.2 and added to the number of fixed seats.

The occupant load of wheelchair spaces and the associated companion seat shall be based on one occupant for each wheelchair space and one occupant for the associated companion seat provided in accordance with Section 1108.2.3.

For areas having fixed seating without dividing arms, the occupant load shall be not less than the number of seats based on one person for each 18 inches (457 mm) of seating length.

The occupant load of seating booths shall be based on one person for each 24 inches (610 mm) of booth seat length measured at the backrest of the seating booth.

Yards, patios, courts and similar outdoor areas accessible to and usable by the building occupants shall be provided with means of egress as required by this chapter. The occupant load of such outdoor areas shall be assigned by the building official in accordance with the anticipated use. Where outdoor areas are to be used by persons in addition to the occupants of the building, and the path of egress travel from the outdoor areas passes through the building, means of egress requirements for the building shall be based on the sum of the occupant loads of the building plus the outdoor areas.
Exceptions:
  1. Outdoor areas used exclusively for service of the building need only have one means of egress.
  2. Both outdoor areas associated with Group R-3 and individual dwelling units of Group R-2.

Where a building contains two or more occupancies, the means of egress requirements shall apply to each portion of the building based on the occupancy of that space. Where two or more occupancies utilize portions of the same means of egress system, those egress components shall meet the more stringent requirements of all occupancies that are served.

diagrams.title: Means of Egress: Multiple Occupancies
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
When a building is comprised of multiple occupancies, the means of egress serving each occupancy shall apply to that portion of the building for which it is provided.

Example 1: in a building that is part B occupancy and part H-4 occupancy where each is provided it's own exit corridor, the exit corridor within and exclusively serving the B occupancy need not be rated and the exit corridor within and exclusively serving the H-4 occupancy is required to have a 1-hour fire resistance (per Table 1020.1). When a means of egress component is utilized or shared by two or more occupancies the component shall be required to meet the most stringent requirements of the occupancies served.

Example 2: in a mixed use building where a B occupancy and an H-4 occupancy share an exit corridor the exit corridor must have a 1-hour fire resistance rating as that (as we know from Example 1) is the most stringent corridor requirement of the uses that will share the corridor. The applicable requirements apply to the entire component, not just the walls or elements adjacent to each occupancy, i.e. both sides of the corridor for the entire length in the example would be required to meet the requirements for 1-hour fire resistant construction for it to be shared by both a B and H-4 occupancy.

children.body:
All portions of the means of egress system shall be sized in accordance with this section.
Exception: Aisles and aisle accessways in rooms or spaces used for assembly purposes complying with Section 1029.

diagrams.title: Corridor Widths in Hospitals
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The Life and Safety Code and the Building Code. Section 18.2.3.4 of Life and Safety Code calls for exit access corridors to have width not less than 8'. Section 1020.3 of the building code calls for the width to be the greater width as determined by occupant load per section 1005.1 or per Table 1020.2 (or Table 1020.3). This table calls for 96" minimum width for exit access corridors in areas required for bed movement and 44" minimum width in areas where bed movement is not required. The width may be reduced to 6' at fixed furniture provided the width meets the occupant load egress required per section 1005.1 of the building code. The hospital facilities guidelines code calls for corridor width to comply with two other codes.

diagrams.title: Egress: Min. Reqs., Existing Buildings
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1001.2 is to ensure that the means of egress in an existing building are not altered beyond what the code considers safe. It requires that the number of required exits is not reduced below the code required minimum for any area, space or building. It also requires that the means of egress width and capacity of the various means of egress elements that comprise the system are not reduced below the code required minimum and would apply to all required elements of the means of egress.

diagrams.title: Aisles with Tables and Fixtures
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Aisle accessways and aisles must be maintained in areas where non-fixed seating exists. Chairs and tables are easy to be moved, rearranged and placed in locations that block aisle accessways and aisles. Even though this is not typically a feature installed during construction, the design of the space and operations after occupancy must continue to consider this code requirement.

children.body: The minimum width, in inches (mm), of any means of egress components shall be not less than that specified for such component, elsewhere in this code.
The required capacity, in inches (mm), of the means of egress for any room, area, space or story shall be not less than that determined in accordance with Sections 1005.3.1 and 1005.3.2:
children.displayTitle: 1005.3 Required Capacity Based on Occupant Load
children.titleText: Required Capacity Based on Occupant Load

children.body:
The capacity, in inches, of means of egress stairways shall be calculated by multiplying the occupant load served by such stairways by a means of egress capacity factor of 0.3 inch (7.6 mm) per occupant. Where stairways serve more than one story, only the occupant load of each story considered individually shall be used in calculating the required capacity of the stairways serving that story.
Exceptions:
  1. For other than Group H and I-2 occupancies, the capacity, in inches (mm), of the means of egress stairways shall be calculated by multiplying the occupant load served by the stairway by a means of egress capacity factor of 0.2 inch (5.1 mm) per occupant in buildings equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 or 903.3.1.2.
  2. Facilities with smoke-protected assembly seating shall be permitted to use the capacity factors in Table 1029.6.2 indicated for stepped aisles for exit access or exit stairways where the entire path for means of egress from the seating to the exit discharge is provided with a smoke control system complying with Section 909.
  3. Facilities with outdoor smoke-protected assembly seating shall be permitted to use the capacity factors in Table 1029.6.3 indicated for stepped aisles for exit access or exit stairways where the entire path for means of egress from the seating to the exit discharge is open to the outdoors.

diagrams.title: Stairway Continuity of Required Width
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where stairways serve more than one story, only the occupant load of each story considered individually shall be used in calculating the required capacity of the stairways serving that story. However, the minimum width or required capacity of the means of egress required from any story of a building shall not be reduced along the path of egress travel until arrival at the public way.

diagrams.title: Example: Concrete Stairs at Elevated Slab
EVACS Systems
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Emergency voice/alarm communications systems (EVACS) are used to alert and instruct occupants on what to do when a fire incident occurs. When a smoke detector, sprinkler system, or manual pull station is activated the EVACS system should sound an alert tone, followed by recorded voice instructions (these instructions should be outlined in the fire safety and evacuation plans per Section 404). In high-rise buildings, in case of fire, the EVACS system only needs to activate on the fire floor, floor above, and floor below. Additionally, EVACS speakers are to be provided throughout the building by paging zones - every floor, elevator groups, areas of refuge, and interior stairways. All EVACS systems are to be designed, installed, tested, and maintained in accordance with NFPA 72, National Fire Alarm and Signaling Code.

For floors utilizing stairs as a means of egress the minimum required combined width of the stairs is determined by multiplying the occupant load for the floor served by the egress capacity factor of 0.3". Egress stairs must be built in accordance with Section 1011, which requires a 44" minimum stair width. Exceptions apply for buildings protected throughout by an automatic sprinkler system and protected by an EVACS system, for smoke-protected assembly seating, and for open air assembly seating.

diagrams.title: Stair Width with Chair Lift (Metal Pan Condition)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 1011.2 defines the required exit stair width. The required width is based on the Occupant load served by the stairway. The minimum width required is 0.3" per occupant per section 1005.1 but not less than 44". There are a few exceptions: The code does allow for 36" wide stairs for stairs that serve and occupant load of <50. Spiral stairs width is covered by section 1011.10. Stairways that serve R-3 occupancy or are within R-2 dwelling units with a folding inclined platform or stairway chairlift must have 20" clear passage measured at the folded lift.

Commentary: Encroachment of stringers appear to depend on if it is a structural member, or just a skirt trim board. If the stringer is a structural element, then 1005.7.2 would seem to prohibit the obstruction, and the stair width would need to be measured between the face of stringers. However, if it were a non-structural trim piece such as a skirt board, then a projection may be allowed. Check with your local building official for the final interpretation of allowed projections into a stairway.

diagrams.title: Min. Stairway Widths - Exceptions (VA and DC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: There are three conditions in which the occupant egress capacity factor changes when determining minimum stairway egress width. In a building that is fully sprinklered, the occupant egress capacity factor can be increased to 0.2" per person. This does not apply to Group H or I-2 occupancy classifications. In a facility having smoke-protected assembly seating the occupant egress capacity factor for stepped aisles shown in Table 1029.6.2 can be used. The smoke control system must comply with Section 909. In a facility having outdoor smoke-protected assembly seating the occupant egress capacity factor for stepped aisles shown in Section 1029.6.3 can be used.

children.body:
The capacity, in inches, of means of egress components other than stairways shall be calculated by multiplying the occupant load served by such component by a means of egress capacity factor of 0.2 inch (5.1 mm) per occupant.
Exceptions:
  1. For other than Group H and I-2 occupancies, the capacity, in inches (mm), of means of egress components other than stairways shall be calculated by multiplying the occupant load served by such component by a means of egress capacity factor of 0.15 inch (3.8 mm) per occupant in buildings equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 or 903.3.1.2.
  2. Facilities with smoke-protected assembly seating shall be permitted to use the capacity factors in Table 1029.6.2 indicated for level or ramped aisles for means of egress components other than stairways where the entire path for means of egress from the seating to the exit discharge is provided with a smoke control system complying with Section 909.
  3. Facilities with outdoor smoke-protected assembly seating shall be permitted to use the capacity factors in Table 1029.6.3 indicated for level or ramped aisles for means of egress components other than stairways where the entire path for means of egress from the seating to the exit discharge is open to the outdoors.

children.titleText: Distribution of Minimum Width and Required Capacity

children.body: Where the means of egress from stories above and below converge at an intermediate level, the capacity of the means of egress from the point of convergence shall be not less than the largest minimum width or the sum of the required capacities for the stairways or ramps serving the two adjacent stories, whichever is larger.
Encroachments into the required means of egress width shall be in accordance with the provisions of this section.

diagrams.title: Corridors: Unobstructed Width
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The unobstructed width of a corridor is determined based on the specific occupancy and utilization of the structure. Corridors must maintain their minimum required width or capacity unobstructed, to ensure safe and easy passage. However, under specific circumstances, exceptions are allowed which include encroachments complying with Section 1005.7.

diagrams.title: Encroachment into Means of Egress Width
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The example shown is for ambulatory care. The restrictions on door swing shall not apply to doors within individual dwelling units and sleeping units of Group R-2 occupancies and dwelling units of Group R-3 occupancies. Door hardware is exempt from the encroachment requirements, provided it complies with Exception 1.

children.body:
Doors, when fully opened, shall not reduce the required width by more than 7 inches (178 mm). Doors in any position shall not reduce the required width by more than one-half.
Exceptions:
  1. Surface-mounted latch release hardware shall be exempt from inclusion in the 7-inch maximum (178 mm) encroachment where both of the following conditions exist:
    1. The hardware is mounted to the side of the door facing away from the adjacent wall where the door is in the open position.
    2. The hardware is mounted not less than 34 inches (865 mm) nor more than 48 inches (1219 mm) above the finished floor.
  2. The restrictions on door swing shall not apply to doors within individual dwelling units and sleeping units of Group R-2 occupancies and dwelling units of Group R-3 occupancies.

children.body:
Handrail projections shall be in accordance with the provisions of Section 1014.8. Other nonstructural projections such as trim and similar decorative features shall be permitted to project into the required width not more than 11/2 inches (38 mm) on each side.
Exception: Projections are permitted in corridors within Group I-2 Condition 1 in accordance with Section 407.4.3.

diagrams.title: Means of Egress Continuity: Obstructions
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Obstructions by building elements are not permitted to be installed within the means of egress. For example, where a minimum egress width of 44" is required, no obstruction or building element can project into the 44" space, which would decrease the width of the space. If the required width is 44", but the total width of the corridor is 50" then a building element could project up to 6" into the space. This would not impede or decrease the required egress width.

Obstructions must also comply with provisions for projections and obstructions in the applicable accessibility code / ADA. While some obstructions or projections may be allowed by egress provisions, they may require special treatment so not to provide a hazard to the vision impaired.

diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Generally, projections of more than 4" are not allowed into the circulation path. This doesn't include the 48" clear width between handrails for stairways used as an accessible means of egress.

The allowance for a 1-1/2" projection into the required width for trim or other non-structural projection at the base would not include structural items such as stringers for steel pan-tread type stairways. The minimum required stair width would have to be accommodated for between the structural items in that condition.

diagrams.title: Protruding Objects: Headroom
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Because circulation paths, walks, corridors, aisles, and passageways are used for egress and egress access, the code limits the minimum ceiling height to stop smoke and other contaminants from preventing safe egress in the event of an emergency. Section 1003.3.1 ensures that any protruding objects do not lower the ceiling to a point that makes the building egress unreasonably safe. Over areas required for the means of egress protruding objects may reduce the ceiling height to 80" minimum. The aggregate area of protruding objects over a means of egress cannot exceed 50% of the ceiling area of the means of egress. Protruding objects not over the required egress width may be less than 80" when provided with a barrier, often referred to as cane detection. The barrier cannot exceed a height of 27". The code does provide an exception for door stops and closers which may not be less than 78" above the floor.

diagrams.title: Parking Garage Exiting: Vehicular Ramps
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Vehicle access ramps may not generally be used as a means of egress from a parking garage. Vehicles entering or exiting the garage pose a hazard to pedestrians.

diagrams.title: Egress: Min. Reqs., Existing Buildings
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1001.2 is to ensure that the means of egress in an existing building are not altered beyond what the code considers safe. It requires that the number of required exits is not reduced below the code required minimum for any area, space or building. It also requires that the means of egress width and capacity of the various means of egress elements that comprise the system are not reduced below the code required minimum and would apply to all required elements of the means of egress.

diagrams.title: Example: Single Exit Condition
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Single-Occupancy Category B, Non-Sprinklered

Spaces are allowed to have only a single exit if they have less than a prescribed amount of occupants, depending on the occupancy group. Also, the common path of egress travel must be less than that allowed by Table 1006.2.1. However, dead end corridors themselves are not limited when only one exit is required.

diagrams.title: Single Exits: Multiple Occupancies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Single exits are permitted to serve multiple occupancies and multiple stories provided a number of additional limitations are met by the design. For a single exit, exit access stairway or ramp to serve a story with multiple occupancies each occupancy in and of itself must meet the requirements of Table 1006.3.3(1) or Table 1006.3.3(2). In addition where a single exit serves a story or multiple stories the sum of the ratios for each occupancy of the design occupant load divided by the allowable occupant load from Table 1006.3.3(2) for each story served by the exit must not exceed 1. When dwelling units are on a floor, the ratio used for dwelling units in the summation is the number of dwelling units divided by 4.

diagrams.title: Exterior Egress Door Arrangement
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1022.2.2 is to ensure that exits lead to a location that provides adequate escape from the building upon exiting. It ensures that all exits provide adequate access to a public way, either directly or via an exit discharge.

diagrams.title: Required Exits: Three or More

Single-Occupancy Category B, Non-Sprinklered

Spaces are allowed to have only a single exit if they have less than a prescribed amount of occupants, depending on the occupancy group. diagrams.title: Example: OL, Exits and Common Path of Travel
Example: Exit Access Travel Distance
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Common path of egress travel and exit access distances are two different but related concepts. Common path of egress travel measures the distance from the start of egress travel to the point at which occupants have a choice of travel to more than one exit. The exit access travel distance is a cumulative measurement of the common path of travel, and the remaining distance to the nearest exit.

If the common path of egress travel does not provide access to two separate and distinct exits or exit access doorways, within the distance specified by Section 1006, an additional exit or exit access is required. The maximum travel distance in the exit access is dependent on the occupancy group and fire sprinkler status and is limited to that specified by Table 1017.2. So long as the allowable common path of egress travel is met, the exit access travel distance (Table 1017.2) must only be satisfied for the closest exit to the space under consideration.

In the example, a B occupancy with NFPA 13 sprinkler system throughout, the maximum exit access travel distance is 300 feet. Given the dimensions shown, both the common path of egress travel and exit access travel distances are satisfied.

diagrams.title: Example: Manufacturing and Storage Egress

diagrams.descriptionHtml: Boiler, incinerator, and furnace rooms house equipment that operate at high temperatures and pressures. If something goes wrong, there is a potential risk for fires or explosions. Having two exit access doorways ensures that if one exit becomes blocked or compromised, there is an alternative escape route available.

diagrams.title: Ladders: Where Permitted
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Permanent ladders may not be a part of the means of egress from any occupied space. Details related to the ladder construction are in the mechanical code section 306.5. The ladder's structural live load requirements are defined in section 1607.17 of the building code. Permanent ladders may be utilized to provide access to the following types of areas and spaces.
  1. Spaces that only need to be accessed by personnel for the maintenance, repair or monitoring of equipment.
  2. Nonoccupied spaces such as crawl spaces, catwalks, freight elevators or very narrow passageways as may be found in a theater or large mechanical room.
  3. Areas primarily utilized for security, life safety or fire safety such as guard towers and lifeguard stands, typically encountered in institutional occupancies.
  4. In group U occupancies areas not open to the general public.
  5. Roofs that are nonoccupied and do not require a stairway by Section 1011.12.1
  6. Where Section 306.5 of the Mechanical Code allows for ladders to access equipment and appliances.

diagrams.title: Refrigerated Rooms: Exits

Refrigeration machinery rooms can contain hazardous materials, like refrigerants that could leak and displace oxygen, leading to asphyxiation risks. If there's a leak or a fire, personnel inside the room might need an immediate escape route. Having two exits ensures that if one is blocked or compromised, there's a secondary route to safety.

diagrams.title: Horizontal Exit Egress Analysis
diagrams.descriptionHtml: When used correctly, in certain situations, use of a horizontal exit can reduce the number of stairways provided while maintaining a consistent level of protection for all occupants. With certain exceptions, horizontal exits are limited to satisfying no more than 50% of the required exits, exit capacity or exit width required from a space under consideration. diagrams.title: Egress Balcony: Wall Separation
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 1021.2 establishes requirements for the separation between an exterior egress balcony and the interior of the building. In most cases, the wall between interior rooms and the exterior egress balcony needs to meet corridor separation standards, using fire partitions and protected openings. The diagram's left-hand example illustrates this standard situation for a single stairway configuration—architects should design with an assumption that any window or door along the egress balcony must have proper rated protection, as would any opening facing into a corridor.
Single Stairways and Opening Protection
The use of a single stairway is a crucial factor: when only one exit stairway is provided, you do not benefit from the separation exception. This means all doors and windows along the egress balcony must be protected as required for corridors. This is intended to ensure a safe, protected evacuation path in projects where there is no alternate escape route. If openings are left unprotected, it can create a hazardous condition—potential fire and smoke spread from adjacent units or rooms directly to the egress route.

Possible exceptions and edge cases
A common point of confusion arises with occupancy-specific exceptions found in different code sections. While some occupancies may not require corridor protection at certain openings (as listed in Table 1020.2 or elsewhere in the code), this does not generally apply to egress balconies with only one stairway—unless those same occupancies are exempted from corridor separation, the wall and opening protection requirements still apply. For projects utilizing two or more stairways, as depicted in the right-hand diagram, and for layout configurations that avoid dead-end travel past unprotected openings, you can eliminate these wall and protective opening requirements. The key is verifying both multiple egress paths and the absence of dead-end travel conditions for your specific occupancy and balcony arrangement.

Where applicable, cumulative occupant loads from adjacent occupancies shall be considered in accordance with the provisions of Section 1004.1. In each story of a mixed occupancy building, the maximum number of occupants served by a single exit shall be such that the sum of the ratios of the calculated number of occupants of the space divided by the allowable number of occupants indicated in Table 1006.3.2(2) for each occupancy does not exceed one. Where dwelling units are located on a story with other occupancies, the actual number of dwelling units divided by four plus the ratio from the other occupancy does not exceed one.

diagrams.title: Single Exits: Multiple Occupancies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Single exits are permitted to serve multiple occupancies and multiple stories provided a number of additional limitations are met by the design. For a single exit, exit access stairway or ramp to serve a story with multiple occupancies each occupancy in and of itself must meet the requirements of Table 1006.3.3(1) or Table 1006.3.3(2). In addition where a single exit serves a story or multiple stories the sum of the ratios for each occupancy of the design occupant load divided by the allowable occupant load from Table 1006.3.3(2) for each story served by the exit must not exceed 1. When dwelling units are on a floor, the ratio used for dwelling units in the summation is the number of dwelling units divided by 4.

diagrams.title: Assembly: Other Exits - No Main Exit Provided
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Assembly spaces with an occupant load greater than 300 are usually provided with a main entrance. In addition to the main entrance providing egress other means of egress are required. Where a main entrance is provided the other required means of egress combined need to accommodate one-half of the occupant load of the space. Where the main entrance is not well defined or multiple main entries are provided the exits may be distributed around the exterior of the assembly space and must be able to accommodate at least 100 percent of the occupant load of the space. The required means of egress for each level of an assembly space must be arranged and separated from each other in accordance with section 1007.1

diagrams.title: Assembly: Other Exits - Main Exit Provided
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Assembly spaces with an occupant load greater than 300 are usually provided with a main entrance. In addition to the main entrance providing egress other means of egress are required. Where a main entrance is provided the other required means of egress combined need to accommodate one-half of the occupant load of the space. Where the main entrance is not well defined or multiple main entries are provided the exits may be distributed around the exterior of the assembly space and must be able to accommodate at least 100 percent of the occupant load of the space. The required means of egress for each level of an assembly space must be arranged and separated from each other in accordance with section 1007.1

diagrams.title: Egress: Min. Reqs., Existing Buildings
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1001.2 is to ensure that the means of egress in an existing building are not altered beyond what the code considers safe. It requires that the number of required exits is not reduced below the code required minimum for any area, space or building. It also requires that the means of egress width and capacity of the various means of egress elements that comprise the system are not reduced below the code required minimum and would apply to all required elements of the means of egress.

diagrams.title: Remoteness of Exit Access
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Remoteness of exit access stairways or ramps refers to the concept where exits are placed a safe distance apart from each other. This helps ensure that if one exit is blocked or compromised in an emergency situation, occupants can still evacuate the building through alternative routes.

diagrams.title: Exterior Egress Door Arrangement
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1022.2.2 is to ensure that exits lead to a location that provides adequate escape from the building upon exiting. It ensures that all exits provide adequate access to a public way, either directly or via an exit discharge.

diagrams.title: Required Exits: Three or More
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Exits are required to be placed far enough apart to allow independent exiting if one exit is blocked.

UpCodes Note: The exact distance between the third (or forth) exit and the primary exits (first and second) is not clear. The requirement is a performance requirement that it must be a "reasonable" distance apart to provide use if one is blocked. Please check with your local building or fire official regarding the application of this section, as the interpretation of "reasonable distance" may be different between code officials and design professionals.

children.displayTitle: Section 1007 Exit and Exit Access Doorway Configuration
children.titleText: Exit and Exit Access Doorway Configuration

children.body: Exits, exit access doorways, and exit access stairways and ramps serving spaces, including individual building stories, shall be separated in accordance with the provisions of this section.

Where two exits, exit access doorways, exit access stairways or ramps, or any combination thereof, are required from any portion of the exit access, they shall be placed a distance apart equal to not less than one-half of the length of the maximum overall diagonal dimension of the building or area to be served measured in a straight line between them. Interlocking or scissor stairways shall be counted as one exit stairway.
Exceptions:
  1. Where interior exit stairways or ramps are interconnected by a 1-hour fire-resistance-rated corridor conforming to the requirements of Section 1020, the required exit separation shall be measured along the shortest direct line of travel within the corridor.
  2. Where a building is equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Sections 903.3.1.1 or 903.3.1.2, the separation distance shall not be less than one-fourth of the length of the maximum overall diagonal dimension of the area served.

diagrams.title: Exit Separation Distance with Rated Corridors - Excpt. 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: If exit stair enclosures are connected with a one-hour rated corridor, the required exit separation distance can be measured along the shortest direct line of travel within the corridor instead of the standard one-half of the diagonal of the area served (Building Code, Reference: 1007.1.1, Exception 1). The corridor must conform to the requirements of Sections 1020 and 708.

diagrams.title: Example: OL, Exits and Common Path of Travel

children.displayTitle: 1007.1.1 Two Exits or Exit Access Doorways
children.titleText: Two Exits or Exit Access Doorways

children.body:
The separation distance required in Section 1007.1.1 shall be measured in accordance with the following:
  1. The separation distance to exit or exit access doorways shall be measured to any point along the width of the doorway.
  2. The separation distance to exit access stairways shall be measured to the closest riser.
  3. The separation distance to exit access ramps shall be measured to the start of the ramp run.

diagrams.title: Exits from Boiler, Incinerator and Furnace Rooms
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Boiler, incinerator, and furnace rooms house equipment that operate at high temperatures and pressures. If something goes wrong, there is a potential risk for fires or explosions. Having two exit access doorways ensures that if one exit becomes blocked or compromised, there is an alternative escape route available.

children.body: Where access to three or more exits is required, not less than two exit or exit access doorways shall be arranged in accordance with the provisions of Section 1007.1.1. Additional required exit or exit access doorways shall be arranged a reasonable distance apart so that if one becomes blocked, the others will be available.

diagrams.title: Required Exits: Three or More
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Exits are required to be placed far enough apart to allow independent exiting if one exit is blocked.

UpCodes Note: The exact distance between the third (or forth) exit and the primary exits (first and second) is not clear. The requirement is a performance requirement that it must be a "reasonable" distance apart to provide use if one is blocked. Please check with your local building or fire official regarding the application of this section, as the interpretation of "reasonable distance" may be different between code officials and design professionals.

diagrams.title: Stair Separations in High Rise Buildings
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Stairs in high-rise buildings are typically in a core that includes stairs and an elevator core. Separation of stairways is slightly less than typical buildings, possibly because of the central nature of the stairs to the occupied space. However, scissor stairs must only be considered as a single stair because in the event the stair is damaged or unable to service in an emergency, a scissor stair will not provide two independent ways out of the building. In the NYC Building Code, stairs sharing any common wall, floors, ceilings, scissor stair assemblies, or other enclosures shall be counted as one exit stairway.

children.displayTitle: 1007.1.2 Three or More Exits or Exit Access Doorways
children.titleText: Three or More Exits or Exit Access Doorways

children.body: Where two exit access stairways or ramps provide the required means of egress to exits at another story, the required separation distance shall be maintained for all portions of such exit access stairways or ramps.

diagrams.title: Remoteness of Exit Access
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Remoteness of exit access stairways or ramps refers to the concept where exits are placed a safe distance apart from each other. This helps ensure that if one exit is blocked or compromised in an emergency situation, occupants can still evacuate the building through alternative routes.

children.displayTitle: 1007.1.3 Remoteness of Exit Access Stairways or Ramps
children.titleText: Remoteness of Exit Access Stairways or Ramps

children.body: Where more than two exit access stairways or ramps provide the required means of egress, not less than two shall be arranged in accordance with Section 1007.1.3.
children.displayTitle: 1007.1.3.1 Three or More Exit Access Stairways or Ramps
children.titleText: Three or More Exit Access Stairways or Ramps

diagrams.title: Lumens and Footcandles
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A footcandle is the measurement of the amount of light that falls on 1 sf of a surface and is dependent on the light source's intensity and the distance the surface being illuminated is from the light source. Lumens are a measurement of the amount of visible light emitted from a light source, in essences the brightness of the light source. The illumination level of a surface (footcandles) equals the Lumens per square foot that land on the surface, i.e. lumens / projected area in sf = footcandles of illumination.

diagrams.title: Lumens and Footcandles - Calculations
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A footcandle is the measurement of the amount of light that falls on 1 sf of a surface and is dependent on the light source's intensity and the distance the surface being illuminated is from the light source. Lumens are a measurement of the amount of visible light emitted from a light source, in essences the brightness of the light source. The illumination level of a surface (footcandles) equals the Lumens per square foot that land on the surface, i.e. lumens / projected area in sf = footcandles of illumination.

diagrams.title: Stair Illumination Level for Accessibility
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Stairs are required to achieve an illumination level of 1 foot-candle measured at the center of each tread. The first 24" of each landing adjacent to the top or bottom riser stair nosing is required to achieve an illumination level of 1 foot-candle. When in use the same to areas are required to achieve and illumination level of 10 foot-candles. Lighting may be controlled by manual switches top and bottom that enable a disabled user to turn the lighting level up prior to departing the landing for the stair run or via motion sensing lighting switches. Motion sensing controls need to provide fail-safe operation, be activated by occupancy of the stairway or landings, and keep the lights on for a duration of 15 minutes minimum upon each activation. If automatic controls are provided they must be able to turn on the lights for the stairway and its associated landings prior to a step being used.

diagrams.title: Emergency Electrical System: Locations for Illumination
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Spaces requiring two or more exits or access to exits shall have an emergency electrical system to automatically illuminate aisles, corridors, and exit access stairways and ramps.

children.body: Illumination shall be provided in the means of egress in accordance with Section 1008.2. Under emergency power, means of egress illumination shall comply with Section 1008.3.

The means of egress serving a room or space shall be illuminated at all times that the room or space is occupied.
Exceptions:
  1. Occupancies in Group U.
  2. Aisle accessways in Group A.
  3. Dwelling units and sleeping units in Groups R-1, R-2 and R-3.
  4. Sleeping units of Group I occupancies.

The means of egress illumination level shall be not less than 1 footcandle (11 lux) at the walking surface.
Exception: For auditoriums, theaters, concert or opera halls and similar assembly occupancies, the illumination at the walking surface is permitted to be reduced during performances by one of the following methods provided that the required illumination is automatically restored upon activation of a premises' fire alarm system:
  1. Externally illuminated walking surfaces shall be permitted to be illuminated to not less than 0.2 footcandle (2.15 lux).
  2. Steps, landings and the sides of ramps shall be permitted to be marked with self-luminous materials in accordance with Sections 1025.2.1, 1025.2.2 and 1025.2.4 by systems listed in accordance with UL 1994.

In Group I-2 occupancies where two or more exits are required, on the exterior landings required by Section 1010.1.6, means of egress illumination levels for the exit discharge shall be provided such that failure of any single lighting unit shall not reduce the illumination level on that landing to less than 1 footcandle (11 lux).
The power supply for means of egress illumination shall normally be provided by the premises' electrical supply.

In the event of power supply failure in rooms and spaces that require two or more means of egress, an emergency electrical system shall automatically illuminate all of the following areas:
  1. Aisles.
  2. Corridors.
  3. Exit access stairways and ramps.

diagrams.title: Emergency Electrical System: Locations for Illumination
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Spaces requiring two or more exits or access to exits shall have an emergency electrical system to automatically illuminate aisles, corridors, and exit access stairways and ramps.

children.body:
In the event of power supply failure in buildings that require two or more means of egress, an emergency electrical system shall automatically illuminate all of the following areas:
  1. Interior exit access stairways and ramps.
  2. Interior and exterior exit stairways and ramps.
  3. Exit passageways.
  4. Vestibules and areas on the level of discharge used for exit discharge in accordance with Section 1028.1.
  5. Exterior landings as required by Section 1010.1.6 for exit doorways that lead directly to the exit discharge.

diagrams.title: Exterior Exit Stairway and Ramp Protection
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exterior Exit Stairway: An exit component that serves to meet one or more means of egress design requirements, such as required number of exits or exit access travel distance, and is open to yards, courts or public ways.

diagrams.title: Vestibules: Air Leakage, Except. (ASHRAE)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Building entrances that separate conditioned space from the exterior are supposed to be protected with an enclosed vestibule, with all doors opening into and out of the vestibule equipped with self-closing devices. However, there are several situations where an exception is made and vestibules are not required.

diagrams.title: Vestibule Req. (ASHRAE)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Vestibules for required to prevent conditioned air leakage are also required to meet all accessibility requirements for spacing of doors in series. Also vestibules part of the exit discharge must meet emergency power lighting requirements.

diagrams.title: Air Leakage Vestibule
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Vestibules for required to prevent conditioned air leakage are also required to meet all accessibility requirements for spacing of doors in series. Also vestibules part of the exit discharge must meet emergency power lighting requirements.

children.body:
In the event of power supply failure, an emergency electrical system shall automatically illuminate all of the following areas:
  1. Electrical equipment rooms.
  2. Fire command centers.
  3. Fire pump rooms.
  4. Generator rooms.
  5. Public restrooms with an area greater than 300 square feet (27.87 m2).

diagrams.title: Rooms w/ Electrical Equipment: Exits
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exit or exit access doors that serve electrical equipment rooms must swing in the direction of egress travel. In the event of a power failure an emergency electrical system shall automatically provide lighting in electrical equipment rooms. If the room or space served by the exit doorway contains a transformer, an energy storage system such as batteries or a modular data center the exit doorway is required to be equipped with panic or fire exit hardware. If the electrical equipment served by the exit doorway is rated 800 amperes or more and contains overcurrent devices, switching devices or control devices, and the doorway is less than 25 feet from the required working space for the equipment, then the door shall not be provided with a latch or lock other than panic hardware or fire exit hardware.

children.body: The emergency power system shall provide power for a duration of not less than 90 minutes and shall consist of storage batteries, unit equipment or an on-site generator. The installation of the emergency power system shall be in accordance with Section 2702.

Emergency lighting facilities shall be arranged to provide initial illumination that is not less than an average of 1 footcandle (11 lux) and a minimum at any point of 0.1 footcandle (1 lux) measured along the path of egress at floor level. Illumination levels shall be permitted to decline to 0.6 footcandle (6 lux) average and a minimum at any point of 0.06 footcandle (0.6 lux) at the end of the emergency lighting time duration. A maximum-to-minimum illumination uniformity ratio of 40 to 1 shall not be exceeded. In Group I-2 occupancies, failure of any single lighting unit shall not reduce the illumination level to less than 0.2 foot-candle (2.2 lux).

diagrams.title: Lumens and Footcandles
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A footcandle is the measurement of the amount of light that falls on 1 sf of a surface and is dependent on the light source's intensity and the distance the surface being illuminated is from the light source. Lumens are a measurement of the amount of visible light emitted from a light source, in essences the brightness of the light source. The illumination level of a surface (footcandles) equals the Lumens per square foot that land on the surface, i.e. lumens / projected area in sf = footcandles of illumination.
