children.body: Porches and decks that are enclosed with insect screening shall be provided with guards where the walking surface is located more than 30 inches (762 mm) above the floor or grade below.

Guards shall be provided where various components that require service are located within 10 feet (3048 mm) of a roof edge or open side of a walking surface and such edge or open side is located more than 30 inches (762 mm) above the floor, roof or grade below. The guard shall extend not less than 30 inches (762 mm) beyond each end of such components. The guard shall be constructed so as to prevent the passage of a sphere 21 inches (533 mm) in diameter.
Exception: Guards are not required where permanent fall arrest/restraint anchorage connector devices that comply with ANSI/ASSE Z 359.1 are affixed for use during the entire roof covering lifetime. The devices shall be reevaluated for possible replacement when the entire roof covering is replaced. The devices shall be placed not more than 10 feet (3048 mm) on center along hip and ridge lines and placed not less than 10 feet (3048 mm) from the roof edge or open side of the walking surface.

diagrams.title: Guards: Mechanical Equip. & Roof Access
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Guards at the roof level are required to protect those servicing equipment or for other reasons from falls. OSHA requirements may be more restrictive and require protection outside of the 10 foot limits in the Mechanical Code at which no guards are required. Other requirements found in laws adopting the Uniform Mechanical code may appear less restrictive than the Building Code, however, the most restrictive requirement for your situation would apply. The links provided here may not be all inclusive, and more stringent local and state requirements may apply.

children.body:
Guards shall be provided where the roof hatch opening is located within 10 feet (3048 mm) of a roof edge or open side of a walking surface and such edge or open side is located more than 30 inches (762 mm) above the floor, roof or grade below. The guard shall be constructed so as to prevent the passage of a sphere 21 inches (533 mm) in diameter.
Exception: Guards are not required where permanent fall arrest/restraint anchorage connector devices that comply with ANSI/ASSE Z 359.1 are affixed for use during the entire roof covering lifetime. The devices shall be reevaluated for possible replacement when the entire roof covering is replaced. The devices shall be placed not more than 10 feet (3048 mm) on center along hip and ridge lines and placed not less than 10 feet (3048 mm) from the roof edge or open side of the walking surface.

Windows in Group R-2 and R-3 buildings including dwelling units, where the top of the sill of an operable window opening is located less than 36 inches above the finished floor and more than 72 inches (1829 mm) above the finished grade or other surface below on the exterior of the building, shall comply with one of the following:
  1. Operable windows where the top of the sill of the opening is located more than 75 feet (22 860 mm) above the finished grade or other surface below and that are provided with window fall prevention devices that comply with ASTM F2006.
  2. Operable windows where the openings will not allow a 4-inch-diameter (102 mm) sphere to pass through the opening when the window is in its largest opened position.
  3. Operable windows where the openings are provided with window fall prevention devices that comply with ASTM F2090.
  4. Operable windows that are provided with window opening control devices that comply with Section 1015.8.1.

diagrams.title: Window Fall Protection
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Window fall protection is a safety measure implemented to prevent accidents and injuries, especially for children, due to falls from windows. It typically involves installing devices like window guards, safety nets, window stops, or window-opening control devices that restrict the extent a window can be opened, making it difficult to accidentally fall through the window.

Installation of window fall protection measures ensures that the occupants of a building remain safe from potential accidents. These safety measures are especially crucial in multi-story buildings, where the risk of severe injury or fatalities due to window falls is higher.

diagrams.title: Window Opening Control Devices
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Window Opening Control Devices are safety devices installed on windows to limit the opening size, helping to prevent accidental falls, particularly for children. These devices are designed to restrict the window opening to a maximum of 4 inches, while still allowing for easy operation of the window for egress purposes if needed.

Window Opening Control Devices must comply with the ASTM F2090 standard, ensuring their quality and effectiveness in preventing accidents related to window falls. They should be operational from inside the room without the use of keys or tools. In emergency situations, these devices can be released to allow the window to fully open without compromising the minimum net clear opening area required for emergency escape and rescue openings.

children.body: Window opening control devices shall comply with ASTM F2090. The window opening control device, after operation to release the control device allowing the window to fully open, shall not reduce the minimum net clear opening area of the window unit to less than the area required by Section 1030.2.

diagrams.title: Remoteness of Exit Access
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Remoteness of exit access stairways or ramps refers to the concept where exits are placed a safe distance apart from each other. This helps ensure that if one exit is blocked or compromised in an emergency situation, occupants can still evacuate the building through alternative routes.

diagrams.title: Exit Access, Exit and Exit Discharge
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The building code defines exit, exit access and exit discharge as the following:

Exit Access: That portion of a means of egress system that leads from any occupied portion of a building or structure to an exit.

Exit: That portion of a means of egress system between the exit access and the exit discharge or public way. Exit components include exterior exit doors at the level of exit discharge, interior exit stairways and ramps, exit passageways, exterior exit stairways and ramps and horizontal exits.

Exit Discharge: That portion of a means of egress system between the termination of an exit and a public way.

children.body: The exit access shall comply with the applicable provisions of Sections 1003 through 1015. Exit access arrangement shall comply with Sections 1016 through 1021.

Egress through intervening spaces shall comply with this section.
  1. Exit access through an enclosed elevator lobby is permitted. Access to not less than one of the required exits shall be provided without travel through the enclosed elevator lobbies required by Section 3006. Where the path of exit access travel passes through an enclosed elevator lobby, the level of protection required for the enclosed elevator lobby is not required to be extended to the exit unless direct access to an exit is required by other sections of this code.
  2. Egress from a room or space shall not pass through adjoining or intervening rooms or areas, except where such adjoining rooms or areas and the area served are accessory to one or the other, are not a Group H occupancy and provide a discernible path of egress travel to an exit.
    Exception: Means of egress are not prohibited through adjoining or intervening rooms or spaces in a Group H, S or F occupancy where the adjoining or intervening rooms or spaces are the same or a lesser hazard occupancy group.
  3. An exit access shall not pass through a room that can be locked to prevent egress.
  4. Means of egress from dwelling units or sleeping areas shall not lead through other sleeping areas, toilet rooms or bathrooms.
  5. Egress shall not pass through kitchens, storage rooms, closets or spaces used for similar purposes.
Exceptions:
  1. Means of egress are not prohibited through a kitchen area serving adjoining rooms constituting part of the same dwelling unit or sleeping unit.
  2. Means of egress are not prohibited through stockrooms in Group M occupancies where all of the following are met:
    1. The stock is of the same hazard classification as that found in the main retail area.
    2. Not more than 50 percent of the exit access is through the stockroom.
    3. The stockroom is not subject to locking from the egress side.
    4. There is a demarcated, minimum 44-inch-wide (1118 mm) aisle defined by full- or partial-height fixed walls or similar construction that will maintain the required width and lead directly from the retail area to the exit without obstructions.

diagrams.title: Cumulative Occ. Loads: Intervening Spaces/Accessory Areas
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Cumulative occupant loads affect egress design when occupants must pass through shared or intervening spaces en route to an exit. When multiple rooms discharge through a common space, that space must be designed to accommodate the total number of occupants that pass through it—not just its own occupant load.

This approach ensures the egress system is appropriately sized for actual use conditions. However, it's important to understand that this requirement applies only to the occupants who traverse the shared path. If a space has multiple exit routes and some occupants do not use the intervening area, only those who do contribute to the cumulative load at that point. This avoids artificially inflating the required egress capacity by counting occupants twice.

Architects should take care during the early planning stages to analyze not just the occupant load of rooms, but also the actual flow of occupants during egress, tracing how people move through space and identifying bottlenecks. It's especially important in open or hybrid layouts—such as coworking areas, medical offices, or tenant spaces within larger occupancies—where paths of travel may be shared or split. Misinterpreting who contributes to the cumulative load can lead to over- or under-designing critical egress components, affecting code compliance and occupant safety.

diagrams.title: Fire Service Elev: Smoke Proof Enclosure
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire Service Access Elevators (FSAE) provide a protected means by which firefighters can access occupied building floors more than 120 feet above the lowest level of fire apparatus access. When FSAE are required by 403.6.1, they need to meet the requirements of 3007, including provision for a lobby meeting 3007.6. Lobbies for FSAE must meet specified criteria, including:
  • Lobby is not required for FSAE opening at level of exit discharge
  • FSAE Lobby must have direct access to an interior exit stairway/ramp or by way of an approved path, constructed consistent with requirements of FSAE lobby
  • FSAE lobby must be enclosed by 1-hour smoke barrier
  • FSAE lobby doorways must have minimum 3/4 hour rating meeting smoke/draft control requirements of 716.2.2.1.1
  • 3/4 hour fire door(s) / smoke and draft control assembly(ies)
  • FSAE lobby must be minimum 150 square feet with least dimension not less than 8 feet

NOTE: Stairs or ramps serving floors more than 75 feet above the lowest level of fire department vehicle access shall be a smokeproof enclosure per 403.5.4, designed in accordance with 909.20. Where 3007.6.1 requires direct access from the FSAE to an interior exit stairway or ramp, this should be taken to mean direct access to the smokeproof enclosure that includes the stairway or ramp, such that the FSAE lobby does not compromise the integrity of the smokeproof enclosure. It would be acceptable to have the FSAE lobby directly access a open exterior balcony, ventilated vestibule or pressurized entrance vestibule that provides access to the pressurized stair, as established in 909.20.

diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where it is necessary to access an exit through another space, certain provision must be in place for this to be allowed. Otherwise, access through an intervening space to an exit is prohibited. This section outlines those areas where accessing through a space to an exit is permissible.

children.body:
Where more than one tenant occupies any one floor of a building or structure, each tenant space, dwelling unit and sleeping unit shall be provided with access to the required exits without passing through adjacent tenant spaces, dwelling units and sleeping units.
Exception: The means of egress from a smaller tenant space shall not be prohibited from passing through a larger adjoining tenant space where such rooms or spaces of the smaller tenant occupy less than 10 percent of the area of the larger tenant space through which they pass; are the same or similar occupancy group; a discernible path of egress travel to an exit is provided; and the means of egress into the adjoining space is not subject to locking from the egress side. A required means of egress serving the larger tenant space shall not pass through the smaller tenant space or spaces.

diagrams.title: Travel Distance Increase: Group F-1 and S-1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In group F-1 and S-1 under special conditions the code allows for the exit access travel to be increased to 400'. All of the following need to be complied with for the increase to be allowed. The building needs to be equipped throughout with a sprinkler system per section 903.1.1.1. The part of the building that is classified as F-1 or S-1 may only be 1 story in height. The ceiling or bottom of the roof deck above the F-1 or S-1 portion of the building must be at least 24' above the floor.

diagrams.title: Travel Distance Measurement
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exit access travel distance needs to be established for each and every room area or space within a facility. The distance is measured from the most remote location in each space required to be evaluated to the nearest available exit or exit entrance. Exit access travel distance on exit access stairways is at the center line of the stairs tangent to the stair nosings, i.e. it is not the horizontal projection of the centerline of the stair and needs to be the sloped distance of the stairway run. At ramps the measurement is along the centerline of the sloped ramp surface. At landings for ramps and stairs the travel distance is measured along the center line of the landings. The code has an exception for OPEN parking garages where the travel distance may be measured from the most remote location to the center of the closest riser of an exit access stairway or where the slope starts on and exit access ramp. There is an exception for smoke protect or open air assembly seating which needs to be in accordance with section 1030.7.

children.body: Travel distance within the exit access portion of the means of egress system shall be in accordance with this section.

diagrams.title: Travel Distance to Area of Refuge
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The area of refuge adjacent to a stairwell is considered an a part of the exit feature itself. It is part of the area of higher protection afforded by a stairwell for the means of egress, as an exit component. Therefore, the exit travel distance should be measured to the area of refuge location.

  3. Buildings equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1.
  4. Group H occupancies equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.2.5.1.

diagrams.title: Atriums: Exiting, Pt. 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The maximum exit access travel distance is generally regulated by section 1017. The same is true for travel within an atrium at the level of exit discharge. However, when exit access traverses space open to an atrium, above or below the level of exit discharge, Section 404.9 restricts such travel to 200 feet of the total distance.

For example, if the maximum allowable distance (T-1017.2) is 300 feet, up to 100 feet may occur in tenant/dwelling space then up to 200 feet within the atrium before reaching a qualifying exit. The cumulative exit access travel distance to an exit must not exceed that specified in T-1017.2.

When the level of exit discharge includes an atrium, not more than 50 percent of the required exits may discharge to areas open to the atrium. This is consistent with permissible exit discharge interior to the building, per Section 1028.

diagrams.title: Example: Exit Access Travel Distance
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Common path of egress travel and exit access distances are two different but related concepts. Common path of egress travel measures the distance from the start of egress travel to the point at which occupants have a choice of travel to more than one exit. The exit access travel distance is a cumulative measurement of the common path of travel, and the remaining distance to the nearest exit.

If the common path of egress travel does not provide access to two separate and distinct exits or exit access doorways, within the distance specified by Section 1006, an additional exit or exit access is required. The maximum travel distance in the exit access is dependent on the occupancy group and fire sprinkler status and is limited to that specified by Table 1017.2. So long as the allowable common path of egress travel is met, the exit access travel distance (Table 1017.2) must only be satisfied for the closest exit to the space under consideration.

In the example, a B occupancy with NFPA 13 sprinkler system throughout, the maximum exit access travel distance is 300 feet. Given the dimensions shown, both the common path of egress travel and exit access travel distances are satisfied.

children.body: Exit access travel distances specified in Table 1017.2 shall be increased up to an additional 100 feet (30 480 mm) provided the last portion of the exit access leading to the exit occurs on an exterior egress balcony constructed in accordance with Section 1021. The length of such balcony shall be not less than the amount of the increase taken.

diagrams.title: Egress Balcony: Travel Distance
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where balconies are used as an exit pathway, or part of a means of egress, they must be constructed in accordance with the dimensions for corridors listed in Section 1020. Egress balconies must be separated from the interior of the building by a fire rated wall construction, and protected openings. The wall rating can be omitted if there are at least two stairways from the exit balcony. If the balcony creates a dead end corridor situation, then the fire rating separation requirement can be omitted if the path to the stairwell does not pass any unprotected openings. Balconies must have adequate space open to the outside atmosphere to prevent the build up of smoke and allow for safe occupant escape. The code requires this open space to be a minimum of 50%. Egress balconies must be a minimum of 10' from lot lines, other parts of the same building, and other buildings on the same lot. However, if buildings on the same lot are protected in accordance with Section 705, then the 10' clearance can be decreased or eliminated.

children.body:
The maximum exit access travel distance shall be 400 feet (122 m) in Group F-1 or S-1 occupancies where all of the following conditions are met:
  1. The portion of the building classified as Group F-1 or S-1 is limited to one story in height.
  2. The minimum height from the finished floor to the bottom of the ceiling or roof slab or deck is 24 feet (7315 mm).
  3. The building is equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1.

diagrams.title: Travel Distance Increase: Group F-1 and S-1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In group F-1 and S-1 under special conditions the code allows for the exit access travel to be increased to 400'. All of the following need to be complied with for the increase to be allowed. The building needs to be equipped throughout with a sprinkler system per section 903.1.1.1. The part of the building that is classified as F-1 or S-1 may only be 1 story in height. The ceiling or bottom of the roof deck above the F-1 or S-1 portion of the building must be at least 24' above the floor.

children.body:
Exit access travel distance shall be measured from the most remote point within a story along the natural and unobstructed path of horizontal and vertical egress travel to the entrance to an exit.
Exception: In open parking garages, exit access travel distance is permitted to be measured to the closest riser of an exit access stairway or the closest slope of an exit access ramp.

Travel distance on exit access stairways or ramps shall be included in the exit access travel distance measurement. The measurement along stairways shall be made on a plane parallel and tangent to the stair tread nosings in the center of the stair and landings. The measurement along ramps shall be made on the walking surface in the center of the ramp and landings.

diagrams.title: Exit Access Stair: Balconies (Ex. 8)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Stairways serving balconies that end in the main assembly space don't have to be enclosed. But keep in mind that unenclosed exit access stairways are not exits. They are a part of the exit access. When the path of exit access includes unenclosed stairways, Section 1017.3.1 requires the distance of travel on such means of egress components to be included in the total travel distance measurement. The measurement along stairways must be made on a plane parallel and tangent to the stair tread nosings in the center of the stairway. This increases the actual exit path distance compared to a simple plan view measurement.

diagrams.title: Travel Distance Measurement
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exit access travel distance needs to be established for each and every room area or space within a facility. The distance is measured from the most remote location in each space required to be evaluated to the nearest available exit or exit entrance. Exit access travel distance on exit access stairways is at the center line of the stairs tangent to the stair nosings, i.e. it is not the horizontal projection of the centerline of the stair and needs to be the sloped distance of the stairway run. At ramps the measurement is along the centerline of the sloped ramp surface. At landings for ramps and stairs the travel distance is measured along the center line of the landings. The code has an exception for OPEN parking garages where the travel distance may be measured from the most remote location to the center of the closest riser of an exit access stairway or where the slope starts on and exit access ramp. There is an exception for smoke protect or open air assembly seating which needs to be in accordance with section 1030.7.

diagrams.title: Aisles with Tables and Fixtures
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Aisle accessways and aisles must be maintained in areas where non-fixed seating exists. Chairs and tables are easy to be moved, rearranged and placed in locations that block aisle accessways and aisles. Even though this is not typically a feature installed during construction, the design of the space and operations after occupancy must continue to consider this code requirement.

diagrams.title: Aisle Req. by Occ. Group
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Where an aisle or aisle accessway is used as a part of means of egress, it must meet the requirements of this section. The required clearances must be maintained throughout the entirety of the aisle or accessway. For assembly occupancies this section sends the user to Section 1029. For all other occupancy groups the user is sent to section 1005.1, Means of Egress Sizing. This section provides an exception for nonpublic aisles that serve occupant loads of less than 50, for these areas the minimum aisle width can be reduced to 28". Specific to Group M occupancies with merchandise pads, the aisle space between the merchandise pads cannot be less than 30" and the travel distance from these merchandise pads to the path of egress cannot exceed 30'.

Careful attention should also be paid to accessibility requirements of the ADA and state and local accessibility regulations. In such cases where an accessible aisle is required, which includes many work areas, the minimum width is 36", and allows a narrowing of the aisle due to impingements or obstructions to a maximum length of 24" of travel

children.body:
Aisles and aisle accessways serving as a portion of the exit access in the means of egress system shall comply with the requirements of this section. Aisles or aisle accessways shall be provided from all occupied portions of the exit access that contain seats, tables, furnishings, displays and similar fixtures or equipment. The minimum width or required capacity of aisles shall be unobstructed.
Exception: Encroachments complying with Section 1005.7.

children.body: Aisles and aisle accessways serving a room or space used for assembly purposes shall comply with Section 1029.

diagrams.title: Assembly Egress: Tread Contrasting Marking Stripe
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Being able to discern each tread is an important safety feature of stepped aisles in the means of egress for assembly areas.

diagrams.title: Aisles at Tables or Seats: Assembly Occ.
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Rooms used for assembly purposes that contains seats, tables, displays, similar fixtures or equipment are also required to maintain the basic concepts of the means of egress. Many of these items may be placed after the Certificate of Occupancy is issued. It's imperative that the placement be part of any design so that the Owner and their representatives will be able to ensure compliance with this section post-occupancy, without the benefit of inspections by the AHJ. Lack of maintained aisles can lead to a hazardous situation, especially in an event that has full occupancy of the space.

In Group B and M occupancies, the minimum clear aisle width shall be determined by Section 1005.1 for the occupant load served, but shall be not less than that required for corridors by Section 1020.2.
Exception: Nonpublic aisles serving less than 50 people and not required to be accessible by Chapter 11 need not exceed 28 inches (711 mm) in width.

children.body:
An aisle accessway shall be provided on not less than one side of each element within the merchandise pad. The minimum clear width for an aisle accessway not required to be accessible shall be 30 inches (762 mm). The required clear width of the aisle accessway shall be measured perpendicular to the elements and merchandise within the merchandise pad. The 30-inch (762 mm) minimum clear width shall be maintained to provide a path to an adjacent aisle or aisle accessway. The common path of egress travel shall not exceed 30 feet (9144 mm) from any point in the merchandise pad.
Exception: For areas serving not more than 50 occupants, the common path of egress travel shall not exceed 75 feet (22 860 mm).

diagrams.title: Exit Access Stairs: Accessible Means of Egress
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1009.3.1 is to ensure that all different accessible floor areas and levels within the same story are provided with an accessible means of egress as required by section 1009.1. It does so by eliminating exit access stairways that interconnect different levels on the same story as part of an accessible means of egress. Section 1009.3.1 also provides a special exception for exit access stairways that serve mezzanines to be a part of an accessible means of egress.

diagrams.title: Exit Access Stairway Enclosures: I-2 and I-3
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In group I-2 and I-3 occupancies exit access stairways or ramps are always required to be enclosed in a shaft enclosure as required by section 713, 2 hour fire resistance where connecting 4 or more stories and not less than 1 hour fire resistance when connecting less than 4 stories (713.4). There is an exception for I-3 occupancies that allows for 1 interior exit stairway enclosure to be glazed provided all the requirements spelled out in section 408.3.8 are met, but even this exception requires the stairway to be enclosed and essentially a smoke protected environment. In California, this also applies to Group R-2.1 occupancies.

diagrams.title: Exit Access Stairways at Same Story
diagrams.descriptionHtml: An exit access stairway is an essential component of the means of egress system within a building. It connects differing levels within a building, typically serving floor levels within one or multiple stories, and guides occupants towards an exit from the building. When the exit access stairway is serving areas within the same story, those stairways are not required to be enclosed.

diagrams.title: Atriums: Exiting, Pt. 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The maximum exit access travel distance is generally regulated by section 1017. The same is true for travel within an atrium at the level of exit discharge. However, when exit access traverses space open to an atrium, above or below the level of exit discharge, Section 404.9 restricts such travel to 200 feet of the total distance.

For example, if the maximum allowable distance (T-1017.2) is 300 feet, up to 100 feet may occur in tenant/dwelling space then up to 200 feet within the atrium before reaching a qualifying exit. The cumulative exit access travel distance to an exit must not exceed that specified in T-1017.2.

When the level of exit discharge includes an atrium, not more than 50 percent of the required exits may discharge to areas open to the atrium. This is consistent with permissible exit discharge interior to the building, per Section 1028.

diagrams.title: Accessible Means of Egress: Stairways
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A means of egress is an unobstructed path to leave buildings, structures, and spaces. A means of egress is comprised of exit access, exit, and exit discharge. An accessible means of egress, as defined by the code, is a "continuous and unobstructed way of egress travel from any point in a building or facility that provides an accessible route to an area of refuge, a horizontal exit, or a public way." Where more than one means of egress is required from any accessible space, each accessible portion of the space must be served by at least two accessible means of egress. Accessible spaces can be served by one accessible means of egress only where the code permits one means of egress.

children.displayTitle: Section 1019 Exit Access Stairways and Ramps

children.body: Exit access stairways and ramps serving as an exit access component in a means of egress system shall comply with the requirements of this section. The number of stories connected by exit access stairways and ramps shall include basements, but not mezzanines.
Exit access stairways and ramps that serve floor levels within a single story are not required to be enclosed.

diagrams.title: Exit Access Stairways at Same Story
diagrams.descriptionHtml: An exit access stairway is an essential component of the means of egress system within a building. It connects differing levels within a building, typically serving floor levels within one or multiple stories, and guides occupants towards an exit from the building. When the exit access stairway is serving areas within the same story, those stairways are not required to be enclosed.

children.body:
In other than Group I-2 and I-3 occupancies, floor openings containing exit access stairways or ramps that do not comply with one of the conditions listed in this section shall be enclosed with a shaft enclosure constructed in accordance with Section 713.
  1. Exit access stairways and ramps that serve or atmospherically communicate between only two stories. Such interconnected stories shall not be open to other stories.
  2. In Group R-1, R-2 or R-3 occupancies, exit access stairways and ramps connecting four stories or less serving and contained within an individual dwelling unit or sleeping unit or live/work unit.
  3. Exit access stairways serving and contained within a Group R-3 congregate residence or a Group R-4 facility are not required to be enclosed.
  4. Exit access stairways and ramps in buildings equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1, where the area of the vertical opening between stories does not exceed twice the horizontal projected area of the stairway or ramp and the opening is protected by a draft curtain and closely spaced sprinklers in accordance with NFPA 13. In other than Group B and M occupancies, this provision is limited to openings that do not connect more than four stories.
  5. Exit access stairways and ramps within an atrium complying with the provisions of Section 404.
  6. Exit access stairways and ramps in open parking garages that serve only the parking garage.
  7. Exit access stairways and ramps serving open-air seating complying with the exit access travel distance requirements of Section 1029.7.
  8. Exit access stairways and ramps serving the balcony, gallery or press box and the main assembly floor in occupancies such as theaters, places of religious worship, auditoriums and sports facilities.

diagrams.title: Exit Access Stair: Balconies (Ex. 8)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Stairways serving balconies that end in the main assembly space don't have to be enclosed. But keep in mind that unenclosed exit access stairways are not exits. They are a part of the exit access. When the path of exit access includes unenclosed stairways, Section 1017.3.1 requires the distance of travel on such means of egress components to be included in the total travel distance measurement. The measurement along stairways must be made on a plane parallel and tangent to the stair tread nosings in the center of the stairway. This increases the actual exit path distance compared to a simple plan view measurement.

diagrams.title: Two Story Openings
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In other than Groups I-2 and I-3, a vertical opening that is not used as one of the applications listed in Building Code Section 712.1, such as an atrium or escalator opening, is allowed. If an opening connecting stories is used for listed purposes, other requirements apply. If a two-story opening is used per 712.1.9, the opening must comply with all of the following items:
  1. Does not connect more than two stories.
  2. Does not penetrate a horizontal assembly that separates fire areas or smoke barriers that separate smoke compartments.
  3. Is not concealed within the construction of a wall or a floor/ceiling assembly.
  4. Is not open to a corridor in Group I and R occupancies.
  5. Is not open to a corridor on nonsprinklered floors.
  6. Is separated from floor openings and air transfer openings serving other floors by construction conforming to required shaft enclosures.

According to Section 713, shaft enclosures shall be constructed as fire barriers in accordance with Section 707.

children.displayTitle: 1019.3 Occupancies Other Than Groups I-2 and I-3
children.titleText: Occupancies Other Than Groups I-2 and I-3

children.body:
In Group I-2 and I-3 occupancies, floor openings between stories containing exit access stairways or ramps are required to be enclosed with a shaft enclosure constructed in accordance with Section 713.
Exception: In Group I-3 occupancies, exit access stairways or ramps constructed in accordance with Section 408 are not required to be enclosed.

diagrams.title: Exit Access Stairway Enclosures: I-2 and I-3
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In group I-2 and I-3 occupancies exit access stairways or ramps are always required to be enclosed in a shaft enclosure as required by section 713, 2 hour fire resistance where connecting 4 or more stories and not less than 1 hour fire resistance when connecting less than 4 stories (713.4). There is an exception for I-3 occupancies that allows for 1 interior exit stairway enclosure to be glazed provided all the requirements spelled out in section 408.3.8 are met, but even this exception requires the stairway to be enclosed and essentially a smoke protected environment. In California, this also applies to Group R-2.1 occupancies.

diagrams.title: Corridor Widths in Hospitals
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The Life and Safety Code and the Building Code. Section 18.2.3.4 of Life and Safety Code calls for exit access corridors to have width not less than 8'. Section 1020.3 of the building code calls for the width to be the greater width as determined by occupant load per section 1005.1 or per Table 1020.2 (or Table 1020.3). This table calls for 96" minimum width for exit access corridors in areas required for bed movement and 44" minimum width in areas where bed movement is not required. The width may be reduced to 6' at fixed furniture provided the width meets the occupant load egress required per section 1005.1 of the building code. The hospital facilities guidelines code calls for corridor width to comply with two other codes.

diagrams.title: Corridors: Air Movement Above Corridor
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1020.6.1 addresses how and when the space above the ceiling of a corridor may be utilized as a return air plenum and calls for 1 or more of 5 conditions being met to ensure the corridor's safety is not compromised.

diagrams.title: Dead End Corridors
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Dead end corridors provide access to an exit in only one direction. Because of this, they provide a unique hazard in emergency conditions. Therefore, the length of dead end corridors are limited. Dead end corridor lengths are not limited where only one exit or exit access is required.

diagrams.title: Dead End Corridor Measurement
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In facilities or spaces that require access to more than one means of egress, dead-end corridors may not exceed 20 feet in length. The code provides an exception for Group I-3,Condition 2, 3 or 4, occupancies where dead-end corridors may not exceed 50 feet. The code provide an exception for Groups B, E, F, I-1, M, R-1, R-2, S and U, occupancies that are equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system where dead-end corridors may not exceed 50feet. The last exception notes dead-end corridor length is not limited where the corridor's length does not exceed 2.5 times its narrowest width.

Starting with the 2021 year cycle, an exception was added for Group I-2, Condition 2 occupancies. The length of dead-end corridors that do not serve patient rooms or patient treatment spaces shall not exceed 30 feet in that occupancy group.

diagrams.title: Fire Partitions: Corridor Walls
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire partitions are generally required in the following locations:
  1. Walls separating sleeping and/or dwelling units In I-1 and Group R occupancies
  2. Walls separating tenants in open or covered mall buildings
  3. Corridor walls where required by section 1020.0
  4. Walls enclosing elevator lobbies that provide hoistway opening protection
  5. Walls separating egress balconies where required by section 1021.2

diagrams.title: Exit Separation Distance with Rated Corridors - Excpt. 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: If exit stair enclosures are connected with a one-hour rated corridor, the required exit separation distance can be measured along the shortest direct line of travel within the corridor instead of the standard one-half of the diagonal of the area served (Building Code, Reference: 1007.1.1, Exception 1). The corridor must conform to the requirements of Sections 1020 and 708.

diagrams.title: Means of Egress Continuity: Obstructions
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Obstructions by building elements are not permitted to be installed within the means of egress. For example, where a minimum egress width of 44" is required, no obstruction or building element can project into the 44" space, which would decrease the width of the space. If the required width is 44", but the total width of the corridor is 50" then a building element could project up to 6" into the space. This would not impede or decrease the required egress width.

Obstructions must also comply with provisions for projections and obstructions in the applicable accessibility code / ADA. While some obstructions or projections may be allowed by egress provisions, they may require special treatment so not to provide a hazard to the vision impaired.

diagrams.title: Egress Balcony: Wall Separation
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 1021.2 establishes requirements for the separation between an exterior egress balcony and the interior of the building. In most cases, the wall between interior rooms and the exterior egress balcony needs to meet corridor separation standards, using fire partitions and protected openings. The diagram's left-hand example illustrates this standard situation for a single stairway configuration—architects should design with an assumption that any window or door along the egress balcony must have proper rated protection, as would any opening facing into a corridor.
Single Stairways and Opening Protection
The use of a single stairway is a crucial factor: when only one exit stairway is provided, you do not benefit from the separation exception. This means all doors and windows along the egress balcony must be protected as required for corridors. This is intended to ensure a safe, protected evacuation path in projects where there is no alternate escape route. If openings are left unprotected, it can create a hazardous condition—potential fire and smoke spread from adjacent units or rooms directly to the egress route.

Possible exceptions and edge cases
A common point of confusion arises with occupancy-specific exceptions found in different code sections. While some occupancies may not require corridor protection at certain openings (as listed in Table 1020.2 or elsewhere in the code), this does not generally apply to egress balconies with only one stairway—unless those same occupancies are exempted from corridor separation, the wall and opening protection requirements still apply. For projects utilizing two or more stairways, as depicted in the right-hand diagram, and for layout configurations that avoid dead-end travel past unprotected openings, you can eliminate these wall and protective opening requirements. The key is verifying both multiple egress paths and the absence of dead-end travel conditions for your specific occupancy and balcony arrangement.

diagrams.title: Corridors: Unobstructed Width
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The unobstructed width of a corridor is determined based on the specific occupancy and utilization of the structure. Corridors must maintain their minimum required width or capacity unobstructed, to ensure safe and easy passage. However, under specific circumstances, exceptions are allowed which include encroachments complying with Section 1005.7.

children.body:
Corridors shall be fire-resistance rated in accordance with Table 1020.1. The corridor walls required to be fire-resistance rated shall comply with Section 708 for fire partitions.
Exceptions:
  1. A fire-resistance rating is not required for corridors in an occupancy in Group E where each room that is used for instruction has not less than one door opening directly to the exterior and rooms for assembly purposes have not less than one-half of the required means of egress doors opening directly to the exterior. Exterior doors specified in this exception are required to be at ground level.
  2. A fire-resistance rating is not required for corridors contained within a dwelling unit or sleeping unit in an occupancy in Groups I-1 and R.
  3. A fire-resistance rating is not required for corridors in open parking garages.
  4. A fire-resistance rating is not required for corridors in an occupancy in Group B that is a space requiring only a single means of egress complying with Section 1006.2.
  5. Corridors adjacent to the exterior walls of buildings shall be permitted to have unprotected openings on unrated exterior walls where unrated walls are permitted by Table 602 and unprotected openings are permitted by Table 705.8.

diagrams.title: Fire Rated Wall Assemblies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Fire rated wall assemblies are of three varieties: fire walls, fire barriers and fire partitions. Fire barriers can be used as shaft enclosures, occupancy separations and others. Fire partitions are often used as demising walls and corridor separations, among other uses.

diagrams.title: Fire Partition Continuity
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Construction requirements for fire partitions include continuity to floors above or below and foundations to preclude the passage of fire and smoke from one area to another, to prevent an "end-run" effect that would compromise the protection provided.

diagrams.title: Means of Egress: Multiple Occupancies
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
When a building is comprised of multiple occupancies, the means of egress serving each occupancy shall apply to that portion of the building for which it is provided.

Example 1: in a building that is part B occupancy and part H-4 occupancy where each is provided it's own exit corridor, the exit corridor within and exclusively serving the B occupancy need not be rated and the exit corridor within and exclusively serving the H-4 occupancy is required to have a 1-hour fire resistance (per Table 1020.1). When a means of egress component is utilized or shared by two or more occupancies the component shall be required to meet the most stringent requirements of the occupancies served.

Example 2: in a mixed use building where a B occupancy and an H-4 occupancy share an exit corridor the exit corridor must have a 1-hour fire resistance rating as that (as we know from Example 1) is the most stringent corridor requirement of the uses that will share the corridor. The applicable requirements apply to the entire component, not just the walls or elements adjacent to each occupancy, i.e. both sides of the corridor for the entire length in the example would be required to meet the requirements for 1-hour fire resistant construction for it to be shared by both a B and H-4 occupancy.

diagrams.title: Egress Balcony: Wall Separation
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 1021.2 establishes requirements for the separation between an exterior egress balcony and the interior of the building. In most cases, the wall between interior rooms and the exterior egress balcony needs to meet corridor separation standards, using fire partitions and protected openings. The diagram's left-hand example illustrates this standard situation for a single stairway configuration—architects should design with an assumption that any window or door along the egress balcony must have proper rated protection, as would any opening facing into a corridor.
Single Stairways and Opening Protection
The use of a single stairway is a crucial factor: when only one exit stairway is provided, you do not benefit from the separation exception. This means all doors and windows along the egress balcony must be protected as required for corridors. This is intended to ensure a safe, protected evacuation path in projects where there is no alternate escape route. If openings are left unprotected, it can create a hazardous condition—potential fire and smoke spread from adjacent units or rooms directly to the egress route.

Possible exceptions and edge cases
A common point of confusion arises with occupancy-specific exceptions found in different code sections. While some occupancies may not require corridor protection at certain openings (as listed in Table 1020.2 or elsewhere in the code), this does not generally apply to egress balconies with only one stairway—unless those same occupancies are exempted from corridor separation, the wall and opening protection requirements still apply. For projects utilizing two or more stairways, as depicted in the right-hand diagram, and for layout configurations that avoid dead-end travel past unprotected openings, you can eliminate these wall and protective opening requirements. The key is verifying both multiple egress paths and the absence of dead-end travel conditions for your specific occupancy and balcony arrangement.

diagrams.title: Required Fire Ratings for Protective Wall Assemblies
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The various wall assemblies outlined in the table represent a hierarchy of fire and smoke protection strategies, each serving a specific code-defined function. Fire walls, governed by BC 706, provide the highest level of protection. They are structurally independent and typically rated for 3 to 4 hours, intended to subdivide buildings into separate code-compliant structures. This makes them essential in controlling fire area limits and enabling larger building footprints.

Fire barriers under BC 707 are slightly less stringent but highly versatile. With ratings ranging from 1 to 4 hours, they are commonly used to separate occupancies, vertical shafts, and hazardous areas. Unlike fire walls, they are not required to be structurally independent, making them more adaptable in multi-story construction while still offering robust fire containment.

Moving further down the spectrum, fire partitions (BC 708) and smoke barriers (BC 709) typically carry 1-hour ratings. Fire partitions are used in less critical separations such as between dwelling units or corridors, while smoke barriers are designed to limit the spread of smoke across smoke compartments, particularly in healthcare occupancies. Smoke partitions (BC 710), by contrast, have no fire rating but are required to resist smoke passage, making them suitable for spaces like corridors in sprinklered buildings.

Lastly, protection for sprinklered incidental uses (BC 509.4.2) can sometimes forgo a fire-resistance rating altogether if automatic sprinklers are provided. This reflects a performance-based allowance in the code that balances passive and active fire protection measures. Understanding the distinctions among these wall types is key for aligning life safety objectives with code compliance and constructibility.

diagrams.title: Egress Balcony: Travel Distance
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where balconies are used as an exit pathway, or part of a means of egress, they must be constructed in accordance with the dimensions for corridors listed in Section 1020. Egress balconies must be separated from the interior of the building by a fire rated wall construction, and protected openings. The wall rating can be omitted if there are at least two stairways from the exit balcony. If the balcony creates a dead end corridor situation, then the fire rating separation requirement can be omitted if the path to the stairwell does not pass any unprotected openings. Balconies must have adequate space open to the outside atmosphere to prevent the build up of smoke and allow for safe occupant escape. The code requires this open space to be a minimum of 50%. Egress balconies must be a minimum of 10' from lot lines, other parts of the same building, and other buildings on the same lot. However, if buildings on the same lot are protected in accordance with Section 705, then the 10' clearance can be decreased or eliminated.

diagrams.title: Fire Partitions: Corridor Walls
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire partitions are generally required in the following locations:
  1. Walls separating sleeping and/or dwelling units In I-1 and Group R occupancies
  2. Walls separating tenants in open or covered mall buildings
  3. Corridor walls where required by section 1020.0
  4. Walls enclosing elevator lobbies that provide hoistway opening protection
  5. Walls separating egress balconies where required by section 1021.2

children.body:
The required capacity of corridors shall be determined as specified in Section 1005.1, but the minimum width shall be not less than that specified in Table 1020.2.
Exception: In Group I-2 occupancies, corridors are not required to have a clear width of 96 inches (2438 mm) in areas where there will not be stretcher or bed movement for access to care or as part of the defend-in-place strategy.

diagrams.title: Corridor Widths in Hospitals
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The Life and Safety Code and the Building Code. Section 18.2.3.4 of Life and Safety Code calls for exit access corridors to have width not less than 8'. Section 1020.3 of the building code calls for the width to be the greater width as determined by occupant load per section 1005.1 or per Table 1020.2 (or Table 1020.3). This table calls for 96" minimum width for exit access corridors in areas required for bed movement and 44" minimum width in areas where bed movement is not required. The width may be reduced to 6' at fixed furniture provided the width meets the occupant load egress required per section 1005.1 of the building code. The hospital facilities guidelines code calls for corridor width to comply with two other codes.

diagrams.title: Corridors: Unobstructed Width
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The unobstructed width of a corridor is determined based on the specific occupancy and utilization of the structure. Corridors must maintain their minimum required width or capacity unobstructed, to ensure safe and easy passage. However, under specific circumstances, exceptions are allowed which include encroachments complying with Section 1005.7.

diagrams.title: Encroachment into Means of Egress Width
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The example shown is for ambulatory care. The restrictions on door swing shall not apply to doors within individual dwelling units and sleeping units of Group R-2 occupancies and dwelling units of Group R-3 occupancies. Door hardware is exempt from the encroachment requirements, provided it complies with Exception 1.

children.body:
The minimum width or required capacity of corridors shall be unobstructed.
Exception: Encroachments complying with Section 1005.7.

diagrams.title: Projections in Nursing Home Corridors
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In Group I-2, Condition 1 occupancies, as long as the corridor width is not less than 96", furniture is allowed to project into the corridor as long as the furniture is attached to the floor or wall, does not reduce the clear width to less than 72", is positioned on only one side of the corridor, does not exceed 50 sq. ft. in area, is separated from other furniture pieces by 10' minimum and it is considered as part of the dire and safety plans in accordance with Section 1002.2.

diagrams.title: Means of Egress Continuity: Obstructions
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Obstructions by building elements are not permitted to be installed within the means of egress. For example, where a minimum egress width of 44" is required, no obstruction or building element can project into the 44" space, which would decrease the width of the space. If the required width is 44", but the total width of the corridor is 50" then a building element could project up to 6" into the space. This would not impede or decrease the required egress width.

Obstructions must also comply with provisions for projections and obstructions in the applicable accessibility code / ADA. While some obstructions or projections may be allowed by egress provisions, they may require special treatment so not to provide a hazard to the vision impaired.

diagrams.title: Corridors: Unobstructed Width
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The unobstructed width of a corridor is determined based on the specific occupancy and utilization of the structure. Corridors must maintain their minimum required width or capacity unobstructed, to ensure safe and easy passage. However, under specific circumstances, exceptions are allowed which include encroachments complying with Section 1005.7.

children.body:
Where more than one exit or exit access doorway is required, the exit access shall be arranged such that there are no dead ends in corridors more than 20 feet (6096 mm) in length.
Exceptions:
  1. In occupancies in Group I-3 of Condition 2, 3 or 4, the dead end in a corridor shall not exceed 50 feet (15 240 mm).
  2. In occupancies in Groups B, E, F, I-1, M, R-1, R-2, R-4, S and U, where the building is equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1, the length of the dead-end corridors shall not exceed 50 feet (15 240 mm).
  3. A dead-end corridor shall not be limited in length where the length of the dead-end corridor is less than 2.5 times the least width of the dead-end corridor.

diagrams.title: Dead End Corridors
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Dead end corridors provide access to an exit in only one direction. Because of this, they provide a unique hazard in emergency conditions. Therefore, the length of dead end corridors are limited. Dead end corridor lengths are not limited where only one exit or exit access is required.

diagrams.title: Dead End Corridor Measurement
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In facilities or spaces that require access to more than one means of egress, dead-end corridors may not exceed 20 feet in length. The code provides an exception for Group I-3,Condition 2, 3 or 4, occupancies where dead-end corridors may not exceed 50 feet. The code provide an exception for Groups B, E, F, I-1, M, R-1, R-2, S and U, occupancies that are equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system where dead-end corridors may not exceed 50feet. The last exception notes dead-end corridor length is not limited where the corridor's length does not exceed 2.5 times its narrowest width.

Starting with the 2021 year cycle, an exception was added for Group I-2, Condition 2 occupancies. The length of dead-end corridors that do not serve patient rooms or patient treatment spaces shall not exceed 30 feet in that occupancy group.

diagrams.title: Example: Single Exit Condition
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Single-Occupancy Category B, Non-Sprinklered

Spaces are allowed to have only a single exit if they have less than a prescribed amount of occupants, depending on the occupancy group. Also, the common path of egress travel must be less than that allowed by Table 1006.2.1. However, dead end corridors themselves are not limited when only one exit is required.

children.body:
Corridors shall not serve as supply, return, exhaust, relief or ventilation air ducts.
Exceptions:
  1. Use of a corridor as a source of makeup air for exhaust systems in rooms that open directly onto such corridors, including toilet rooms, bathrooms, dressing rooms, smoking lounges and janitor closets, shall be permitted, provided that each such corridor is directly supplied with outdoor air at a rate greater than the rate of makeup air taken from the corridor.
  2. Where located within a dwelling unit, the use of corridors for conveying return air shall not be prohibited.
  3. Where located within tenant spaces of 1,000 square feet (93 m2) or less in area, utilization of corridors for conveying return air is permitted.
  4. Incidental air movement from pressurized rooms within health care facilities, provided that the corridor is not the primary source of supply or return to the room.

diagrams.title: Corridors: Air Movement Above Corridor
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1020.6.1 addresses how and when the space above the ceiling of a corridor may be utilized as a return air plenum and calls for 1 or more of 5 conditions being met to ensure the corridor's safety is not compromised.

children.body:
Use of the space between the corridor ceiling and the floor or roof structure above as a return air plenum is permitted for one or more of the following conditions:
  1. The corridor is not required to be of fire-resistance-rated construction.
  2. The corridor is separated from the plenum by fire-resistance-rated construction.
  3. The air-handling system serving the corridor is shut down upon activation of the air-handling unit smoke detectors required by the International Mechanical Code.
  4. The air-handling system serving the corridor is shut down upon detection of sprinkler water flow where the building is equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system.
  5. The space between the corridor ceiling and the floor or roof structure above the corridor is used as a component of an approved engineered smoke control system.

diagrams.title: Corridors: Air Movement Above Corridor
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1020.6.1 addresses how and when the space above the ceiling of a corridor may be utilized as a return air plenum and calls for 1 or more of 5 conditions being met to ensure the corridor's safety is not compromised.

diagrams.title: Plenum (definition)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A plenum is an enclosed portion of the building structure, other than an occupiable space being conditioned, that is designed to allow air movement, and thereby serve as part of an air distribution system. The Life Safety Code further defines that at least one duct connects to this component.

diagrams.title: Example: Suspended Ceiling Slip Joint Plan: Corridors
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Suspended ceilings should be braced against lateral movement and against vertical movement due to seismic forces to prevent falling and/or buckling. Such a failure not only endangers the occupants from the supported fixtures, but a failed suspended ceiling can also block egress doors. Free joints allow for the movement of ceilings and walls in a way that does not contribute to compression induced buckling of suspended ceiling members.

source: oshpd.ca.gov OPD CL2.30

Fire-resistance-rated corridors shall be continuous from the point of entry to an exit, and shall not be interrupted by intervening rooms. Where the path of egress travel within a fire-resistance-rated corridor to the exit includes travel along unenclosed exit access stairways or ramps, the fire-resistance rating shall be continuous for the length of the stairway or ramp and for the length of the connecting corridor on the adjacent floor leading to the exit.
Exceptions:
  1. Foyers, lobbies or reception rooms constructed as required for corridors shall not be construed as intervening rooms.
  2. Enclosed elevator lobbies as permitted by Item 1 of Section 1016.2 shall not be construed as intervening rooms.

diagrams.title: Foyers and Lobbies (Group A-1) Pt 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1029.4 provides the requirements that ensure that lobbies may be exited safely and do not reduce the exiting capacity for the associated A-1 assembly space. It requires that the Foyer or Lobby space does not encroach upon or reduce the capacity of any of the components of the required means of egress for the assembly space. The lobby is required to have a direct connection to all of the main entries and exits or it shall be connected by an unobstructed and straight corridor or path of travel to all main entries and exits.

Exterior egress balconies shall have a minimum fire separation distance of 10 feet (3048 mm) measured at right angles from the exterior edge of the egress balcony to the following:
  1. Adjacent lot lines.
  2. Other portions of the building.
  3. Other buildings on the same lot unless the adjacent building exterior walls and openings are protected in accordance with Section 705 based on fire separation distance.
For the purposes of this section, other portions of the building shall be treated as separate buildings.
